name: Lieberman, Lou, MP
text:
—I present the 11th report from the Publications Committee, sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.
Report—by leave—adopted.
—I ask leave of the House to make a statement concerning the activities of the Publications Committee.
Leave granted.
—The Publications Committee presented a report on the future of the parliamentary papers series in December 1997. In accordance with the undertaking given in this report, the committee wishes to provide an update to the House on two of the recommendations and also to comment briefly on other matters in the committee's sphere of responsibilities.
As members would be aware, the parliamentary papers series is a mechanism to 
 access government information by researchers, students, the general public and parliamentarians. As an indexed and annually numbered series of the significant documents which are presented, it is considered a valuable tool. Traditionally, access to the series was only available in print format through state, parliamentary and university libraries. Recommendation 2 of my committee's report in 1997 stated:
Ministers should ensure that agencies for which they have responsibility fulfil the obligation to produce sufficient copies of documents for the parliamentary papers series. A report identifying those agencies which default should be tabled in each House every twelve months.
The committee noted the government, in accepting this recommendation, stated:
The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet wrote to all secretaries of departments and heads of agencies in March 1998 about their responsibility to provide copies of tabled reports for inclusion in the parliamentary papers series.
As in 1997, the committee continues to find that Commonwealth agencies need to be reminded of their obligation to provide sufficient copies for the parliamentary papers series. The committee is now in a position, however, to inform the House that there are no Commonwealth agencies in default of their obligations to provide copies of reports tabled in 1996, 1997 and 1998 for the parliamentary papers series. The committee intends to provide a further report to the House on this matter later next year. The committee also recommended in its 1997 report that:
. . . agencies producing parliamentary papers should publish the documents electronically as well as in print.
As I mentioned a moment ago, documents contained in the parliamentary papers series have traditionally only been available in hard copy. The committee has monitored developments with respect to the availability on the Internet of, in particular, annual reports of Commonwealth agencies and reports of parliamentary committees. The committee is pleased to advise the House that there has been a significant increase in parliamentary and government information available to the public through the Internet since the committee's report was presented in 1997.
The committee also notes the recent Australian National Audit Office report, entitled Electronic service delivery, including Internet use, by Commonwealth government agencies, which stated that 91 per cent of agencies surveyed in this ANAO report had an Internet site to facilitate access to information about those agencies and their services. In relation to parliamentary proceedings, the committee welcomes the recent tabling of a video by another committee, with which I am associated—the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs—illustrating the work of a parliamentary committee and elements of the report of that committee, entitled Unlocking the future, dealing with a review of Northern Territory land rights.
Also, we welcome the recent report called It's your House by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure. This report comments on strategies to increase access to and involvement by the public in House of Representatives committee activities, and in particular the use of audio and video links, appropriate promotion of committee activities in the media and to school students, more innovative development of Internet sites and the extension of televising of House proceedings to committee hearings, particularly through web casting. The committee commends such strategies to the House for its further consideration.

Ministers should ensure that agencies for which they have responsibility fulfil the obligation to produce sufficient copies of documents for the parliamentary papers series. A report identifying those agencies which default should be tabled in each House every twelve months.
The committee noted the government, in accepting this recommendation, stated:
The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet wrote to all secretaries of departments and heads of agencies in March 1998 about their responsibility to provide copies of tabled reports for inclusion in the parliamentary papers series.
As in 1997, the committee continues to find that Commonwealth agencies need to be reminded of their obligation to provide sufficient copies for the parliamentary papers series. The committee is now in a position, however, to inform the House that there are no Commonwealth agencies in default of their obligations to provide copies of reports tabled in 1996, 1997 and 1998 for the parliamentary papers series. The committee intends to provide a further report to the House on this matter later next year. The committee also recommended in its 1997 report that:
. . . agencies producing parliamentary papers should publish the documents electronically as well as in print.
As I mentioned a moment ago, documents contained in the parliamentary papers series have traditionally only been available in hard copy. The committee has monitored developments with respect to the availability on the Internet of, in particular, annual reports of Commonwealth agencies and reports of parliamentary committees. The committee is pleased to advise the House that there has been a significant increase in parliamentary and government information available to the public through the Internet since the committee's report was presented in 1997.
The committee also notes the recent Australian National Audit Office report, entitled Electronic service delivery, including Internet use, by Commonwealth government agencies, which stated that 91 per cent of agencies surveyed in this ANAO report had an Internet site to facilitate access to information about those agencies and their services. In relation to parliamentary proceedings, the committee welcomes the recent tabling of a video by another committee, with which I am associated—the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs—illustrating the work of a parliamentary committee and elements of the report of that committee, entitled Unlocking the future, dealing with a review of Northern Territory land rights.
Also, we welcome the recent report called It's your House by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure. This report comments on strategies to increase access to and involvement by the public in House of Representatives committee activities, and in particular the use of audio and video links, appropriate promotion of committee activities in the media and to school students, more innovative development of Internet sites and the extension of televising of House proceedings to committee hearings, particularly through web casting. The committee commends such strategies to the House for its further consideration.

name: Thomson, Kelvin, MP
text:
—The opposition's position in relation to the amendments coming back from the 
 Senate to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8) 1999  is as follows. There are four amendment categories coming back from the Senate: first, bribes paid to government officials in Australia will cease to qualify as tax deductible; second, environmental gifts to approved environmental bodies, either by way of absolute donation of land or through entering into an environmental covenant over the land, will obtain tax deductible status; third, donations of property worth more than $5,000 to political parties will qualify for only $100, not the $1,500 proposed by the government; and, fourth, tax deductibility will be denied for contributions to private funds where those private funds are engaged in providing moneys or other benefits to political parties.
I am always conscious that my colleagues are very enthusiastic to hear my contributions, but it has also been suggested to me that the sooner we get through this bill the sooner the Senate might be able to rise and, therefore, their enthusiasm might be tempered by that knowledge. I will therefore endeavour to keep my remarks brief. There are two things that are said to be inevitable in life: death and taxes. With the Howard government, there has come a further inevitability, and that is tax laws amendment bills. This one is  Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8) 1999 , and they go up to  Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 10) 1999 . Alongside that stream this year we have seen a new tax package, the GST bills, and then more recently the business tax package. So lots of taxation laws amendment bills.
I will consider each of the categories of amendments coming back from the Senate separately. First, bribes paid to government officials in Australia will cease to qualify as tax deductible. The bill introduced by the government proposes to deny tax deductibility to bribes paid by Australian firms to foreign government officials. There are some exceptions: where the moneys paid are only to speed up processing or where they are related to essential services, such as telephone, mail, water services, et cetera. Labor, and indeed the whole Senate, have no problem with that 
 proposal. It received unanimous support in both the House and the Senate.
Labor's amendments extend that principle which has unanimous support to also deny tax deductibility for bribes paid to Australian government officials. Surely, it is against the public interest for our tax laws to grant a tax deduction for the moneys associated with a serious crime, the crime of bribery. Accordingly, Labor's amendments seek to deny tax deductibility for bribes paid to Australian officials. That principle should not be at issue. It is a principled position taken by Labor and the Senate, and the government should simply accept these amendments.
The second category of amendments relates to environmental gifts to approved environmental bodies either by way of absolute donation of land or through entering into an environmental covenant over land. They will obtain tax deductible status. This group of amendments covers environmental gifts. The amendments extend the government's proposals for increased tax concessions for philanthropy to environmental philanthropy. The amendments propose to create a new type of philanthropy where land-holders donate land of conservation value to approved environmental bodies or, if they enter into environmental covenants over land that they continue to own, the land-holders will be able to claim as a tax deduction the economic loss that they incur as a result.
That seems to me to be a pretty fair proposition. It will be a significant incentive for land-holders, many of whom will be farmers, to conserve remnant ecosystems. At the moment, the situation is that the land-holders generally face an economic incentive to clear the land of its natural habitat. We are aware of great problems, for example, in Queensland but also in other states in relation to land clearing. At present, the economic incentive is there to clear the land and to put it into production either from crops or grazing. The proposal in the amendment which would provide the tax deductible status for these gifts has the support of the Senate, has the support of the entire environmental movement, has the support of the CSIRO and, we suspect, the support of Senator Hill as well.
He came to the Senate to oppose the amendments, but indicated that he actually agreed with the principles behind them. That shows that he supports the proposals, but I suspect that he cynically wants to announce them himself next year and claim them as his own. (Extension of time granted) This legislation is bringing in a new regime of taxation for philanthropy. This bill is therefore the appropriate place to deal with measures that relate to environmental philanthropy, and Labor will be opposing the government proposal to not agree with the Senate amendments.
The third area of amendment is donations of property worth more than $5,000 to political parties qualifying only for up to $100 rather than the $1,500 proposed by the government. An insidious part of the Prime Minister's proposals, which has nothing to do with philanthropy, is his proposal in this bill to have the taxpayer subsidise wealthy benefactors of the Liberal Party. This bill proposes that in the case of taxpayers who give a gift of property worth $5,000 or more to a political party the donor should get a tax deduction of $1,500. This is an outrageous policy which is rejected by Labor and, fortunately, by the Senate. This would have subsidised wealthy political donors and it is without any justification whatsoever in public policy terms. People are free to donate to political parties as they choose, but they should not get a substantial taxpayer subsidy if they happen to be wealthy enough to provide gifts of property worth more than $5,000.
Labor's amendments, which were supported by all the non-government parties in the Senate, simply treat these types of donations as other cash donations to political parties are treated—that is, to limit the tax deductibility to $100. This essentially nominal figure allows equal access to tax benefits for all people who may donate to political parties, both those of means and those of limited means—whereas the government's much higher proposal will simply subsidise the much better off. We reject the use of taxpayer's funds in this regard, just as we reject the use of taxpayer's funds to bankroll 
 shonky political front operations such as the Greenfields Foundation, to which the final amendment relates and to which I now turn.
The final set of amendments relates to denying tax deductibility for contributions to private funds where those funds are engaged in providing moneys or other benefits to political parties. This takes us into the somewhat shadowy area of Liberal Party fundraising. It is worth recounting some of the debate that occurred in the Senate to understand the origin of this amendment, which indeed has arisen expressly from the Senate's consideration of this bill and was not put forward prior to that. Senator Faulkner referred to the Greenfields Foundation in the Senate and to the fact that it has been described as a charitable trust by one of the trustees, Mr Bandle. In a leading Australian newspaper on 23 July 1998, Mr Bandle said:
We are set up as a charitable trust and we have written cheques of approximately $80,000 to charities so far.
Senator Faulkner went on to say:
I want to be absolutely assured that we do not have donations or gifts provided to the Greenfields Foundation, which is a charitable trust, whereby those donors receive a tax deductibility for those donations and whereby at some time those donations, which are not disclosed, go to the benefit of the Liberal Party.
He asked for an assurance from Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, that this would not happen and indicated that, if he were able to receive such an assurance, the matter would be closed. He made reference to the fact that the Greenfields Foundation had a history of endeavouring to get around the disclosure provisions in the electoral act and that it had loaned a very large amount of money to the Liberal Party under the most generous of commercial arrangements imaginable. It had also donated a very small amount of money to charities.
So it was not making direct donations, as one would understand the dictionary definition of `donations', but it was loaning massive amounts of money to the Liberal Party. In that way, it endeavoured to get around the disclosure provisions of the act. Senator Faulkner continued to assist the Assistant Treasurer by seeking from him an undertaking 
 that the Greenfields Foundation would not be operating in this way. The Assistant Treasurer, however, was not willing to take up any of these offers. The opposition came to the conclusion—indeed, it found it very difficult to come to any other conclusion—that the government's intention was to try to shonk its way through in relation to the Greenfields Foundation and to allow a vehicle for either private individuals or major corporations or companies to provide donations to a shonky organisation like the Greenfields Foundation.
The donors themselves received tax deductibility and of course there is no public transparency in this. (Extension of time granted) There is no disclosure of those donations and the donors get tax deductibility. That is not good enough, and no-one would defend the integrity of the electoral laws or the tax laws in such a situation. On that basis we had the fourth set of amendments to deny tax deductibility for contributions to private funds where those funds are engaged in providing moneys or other benefits to political parties. I have now indicated the opposition's position in relation to the four areas of amendment.

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—I move:
That amendments Nos 8, 11 to 14, 17 and 18 be disagreed to.
With respect to Senate amendments Nos 8, 11 to 13 and 17, these amendments propose significant additions to measures contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8) 
 1999  that will provide taxation incentives for personal and corporate philanthropy in Australia. Broadly, the amendments provide that, where a property owner covenants a property for conservation purposes and that results in a reduction in the value of the property, any reduction in the value of the property should be treated as a tax deduction.
The amendments also extend the ability to deduct amounts over five years to such donations; and also where property is donated a capital gains tax exemption should apply. Substantial changes like these need to be considered in depth in the context of their cost as well as their effectiveness. Any decisions need to be taken within the budgetary constraints of government but also with the objective of getting the most effective outcome in terms of conservation. Accordingly, we have moved that the House of Representatives does not accept these amendments.
With respect to the other amendments, Senate amendments Nos 14 and 18, these amendments propose changes to the measure that will allow tax deductibility for donations to what will be known as `prescribed private funds'. Broadly, prescribed private funds will have to operate in the same way as ancillary public funds but will not have to seek and receive funds from the public. The purpose of the amendments is to preclude a fund that provides funds to political parties from being a prescribed private fund.
Item 6 of schedule 5 to the bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 such that a fund can only be a prescribed private fund if it is established solely for the purpose of providing money to a fund or institution that is listed under subdivision 30-B of that act. If a fund is established to provide funds to any non-listed institutions, it cannot be a prescribed private fund. Political parties are not listed in subdivision 30. The amendment therefore is unnecessary, and we therefore wish that the House of Representatives does not accept these amendments.

name: McMullan, Bob, MP
text:
—I want to talk only about what I will call, for the sake of simplicity, the `Greenfields' amendment, the one to which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance 
 and Administration was just referring. The most powerful arguments that the government can put either in the Senate or here against this amendment is the argument that they think it is unnecessary. I have to say that is not what you would call an overwhelmingly powerful argument. I think it is also untrue, which I will come to in a moment.
But what it does show is there is not an argument against it on the merits. They say the purpose of it is achieved but they say it in a way which leaves open several loopholes which cause us some concern. I am not in the slightest doubt the government knows what the loopholes are. So if they are doing that and they are not referring to it, and if the loophole is used in the way which I will refer to and the party which is the majority party of the government would be the principal beneficiary then you cannot blame us for being a bit dubious.
It is true that if a private fund of the sort referred to in this provision, like Greenfields, makes a donation then the consequences outlined by the parliamentary secretary apply. But it is by no means as clear to us, certainly not to me, that other sorts of benefits which such a trust might provide—say, the Greenfields Foundation to the Liberal Party—would have the same effect; for example, if they provided a loan. There is nothing that says explicitly to my satisfaction that if the Greenfields Foundation provided a loan to the Liberal Party they would be excluded. What is it that the Greenfields Foundation does? It provides loans to the Liberal Party. Surprise, surprise! Perhaps it is not covered. We kept pursuing the Assistant Treasurer in the Senate to try to get him to cover this point and, in his usual comprehensive manner, he failed to do so. I was trying to listen attentively to the parliamentary secretary and I did not hear him refer to it either. So there, for one, is a serious loophole.
The second problem is that if an organisation is scheduled as a private fund, there may subsequently be a disallowance, for example. One of the other protections that is claimed is that the listing of such a private fund is a  disallowable instrument. It is a while since I was in the Senate and we do not do much 
 disallowance business in the House, but my recollection is that the regulation applies until it is disallowed. You only need a body to be on the schedule for 24 hours to get all the money through it that you ever wanted to put through.
So the existing provisions are less than watertight, to put it politely. They leak like a sieve. So, for that reason, we are concerned that this provision can be abused. We do not want a provision that says that we can abuse it, either; we want the provision to apply equally to us and to every other political party in the country. There is no body that equates to the Greenfields Foundation in relation to the Labor Party. But some time in the future some other political party might have a similar body. We do not want it to be eligible either. We do not want any political parties to be able to use this backdoor mechanism.
I was very concerned that the Prime Minister, when I asked him about this in question time this afternoon, would not give a commitment to vote for an amendment that prevents abuse of this provision. I am concerned that the government is persisting with its opposition to this amendment. I am concerned about what it says about the integrity of our political system and the integrity of our tax system. We will persist in our strenuous pursuit of this amendment.

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—I just want to stress that the `Greenfields' amendment is unnecessary as the government would need to make a regulation to make the Greenfields organisation a prescribed private fund. And even if the government were disposed to do so, which it is not, the Senate could disallow such a regulation. So that is why we indicate that this particular amendment is unnecessary.
With respect to another matter raised by the member for Fraser, a fund can only operate in relation to its principal purposes. If it is making loans to political parties, it is not carrying on for its principal purposes. Therefore, it could not be a registered private fund.

name: Wilkie, Kim, MP
text:
—Unfortunately, I address this place once again concerned over the regressive actions of the Howard government. I refer in this instance to the proposed removal of the office of the Australian Taxation Office at Cannington in my electorate of Swan and the transfer or loss of over 600 staff. It is necessary to briefly look at history to understand the folly and to appreciate the reasons why the office was established in Cannington and why it is crucial to the local area.
In 1991 the Cannington office was established for certain reasons. It brought the Taxation Office out of its centralised location to the people. The office was designed to serve the 350,000 people in the southern area. The siting of the office was based on good commercial practice due to its being a modern facility which included excellent community access from public transport routes and large areas for parking which would provide a good working environment for staff. The decentralised office would help alleviate the overcrowding in Perth traffic and alleviate parking in the CBD. These factors took into consider 
 ation the operational requirements of the ATO, the need for modern accessible communities and also community access.
However, the government has decided to relocate the facility back to the Northbridge city office. In doing so a number of questions need to be asked. These questions are important to the 600 plus staff who would be affected by the move and the thousands of taxpayers who use the facility annually who would be concerned over any relocation to a centre 15 kilometres away.
In discussions with the stakeholders in the process, including the staff, the union, the local business community and users of the Cannington facility, I have established a number of questions that need to be put to the Treasurer. Amongst these are: will there be any job losses in the associated support industries such as security, cleaning and ground staff? What has been resolved over the accommodation issues? Contrary to the comments of management, queries exist over the lease arrangements and extensions to the central office which have not been specified, and also the lack of available space for staff. All these issues remain unresolved. It is important that the Treasurer also answer questions pertaining to the negative externalities from the move. These include the increases in traffic congestion and the extra time taken in journeys for the public and staff.
There is another issue that also warrants consideration. It goes to the heart of the sort of environment that this government seems to encourage—that is, the shabby and non-transparent manner in which the decision was made. It is quite obvious from the correspondence I have seen that the strategy to relocate was taken well in advance of any consultation with staff or any real discussions with members of the local community. In effect, as usual, absolutely no real dialogue occurred.
Of course the usual lip-service occurred with no meaning, and I can understand the staff having developed a thick hide due to the decline in morale in the service. I can also attest that I have noted much of the correspondence from the ATO management to the staff. I can indicate to members of this House 
 that I was taken back by the glaringly `past tense' syntax of that correspondence that either was poorly covered up or they simply could not be bothered to disguise. I put it to the Treasurer and members of this House that these decisions had already been made and that the involvement of members of the community, staff or users of the ATO would not have really mattered.
I am also compelled to ask the question: what rate of commercial rent is paid at the Cannington office, a suburban complex, as against the Northbridge inner city office? I would also like to see highlighted any calculations on the negative impacts of the centralising of taxation services. If 600 regular staff and thousands of customers are removed from the local area, what is the flow-on effect of the loss of that expenditure on the region? Discussions with interested parties indicate that the impact will be as high as $20,000 per week. That figure is not inclusive of the loss of office rent and associated services. This is particularly relevant given that the area has an unemployment rate of 1.5 per cent above the state average with an annual income for the majority of the population of less than $30,000. I believe that the actual costs in transferring the operations coupled with the hidden extras will be so high that the true costs will never see the light of day. The ATO has an obligation to release this information to stakeholders.
In conclusion, I call on the ATO to reconsider the centralisation of the organisation. By continuing to embrace a decentralised office at Cannington, the ATO would continue to make ATO staff available directly to the public, continue to develop an important service that benefits the local community, alleviate congestion, and allow staff and local taxpayers efficient and effective service in their area. I call on the Treasurer and the management of the tax office in Western Australia to abandon this proposal and keep the service where it is needed—here in Cannington.

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.
The amendments being considered tonight demonstrate the government's commitment to consultation and concern that the new tax system be fair to all Australians. The first amendment provides benefits to the charitable sector and was the subject of representations from the Australian Democrats. It would be appropriate at this time to recognise the constructive role played by the Australian Democrats in the implementation of Australia's new tax system.
The first amendment extends the 50 per cent cost of supply test to non-commercial supplies by charities to 75 per cent. The 
 second amendment again provides benefits to the non-profit sector by lifting the threshold under which branch units of charities can opt out of the GST system. This amendment responds directly to a request from the charitable and not-for-profit sector to significantly reduce compliance needs. The third amendment relates to the funeral agreements and responds to requests from the funeral industry for clarity with respect to the transitional provisions as they apply to the funeral industry.
It is interesting to note that the Australian Funeral Directors Association and the Australian Cemeteries and Crematoria Association have commended the government's approach in making these amendments. In fact, the Assistant Treasurer has received a letter dated 2 December from the Australian Funeral Directors Association stating:
On behalf of all members of the Australian Funeral Directors Association and the Australian Cemeteries and Crematoria Association, please accept our thanks for your recent undertakings to amend legislation relating to the transitional provisions for GST and the funeral industry.
The outcomes as described in your correspondence of 30th November, 1999, were very pleasing and, may I say, very sensible. The amendments have certainly provided clarity and relative ease in the application of GST, particularly for prepaid funerals.
That is an absolutely wonderful recommendation and letter of support from the funerals association. I commend the bills and these amendments to the chamber.

name: Thomson, Kelvin, MP
text:
—As I said earlier this evening, a couple of certainties in life have always been said to be death and taxes. Under the Howard government, a further certainty is amendments to taxation laws. We had Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 10) 1999  on the Notice Paper . Here before us we have the second amendment bill to the government's GST legislation. Indeed, that amendment bill to the GST legislation has now been amended on around 1,000 occasions. We are seeing, in the dying minutes or perhaps hours of this parliament this year, the government come in with further amendments dealing with issues associated with prepaid funerals and charities.
The fact is that embracing the GST is like cuddling a porcupine. At every point the government uncovers problems. In this case it is problems raised by the charities. We will not oppose this legislation, but it does not solve the problems. We welcome the fact that the government has been able to make some changes, but they do not solve the problems. Charities are still caught in the GST net. They are not GST free. This agreement keeps them in that net. As the shadow Treasurer said this afternoon, charities remain trapped in what has become a huge driftnet. The situation is that if a charity is below the $100,000 level it still has to pay GST on its inputs. The GST becomes an embedded tax for charities. It keeps those charities that are below the threshold in the GST net, so they are caught coming and going. The other thing that came out of this afternoon's new and revised deal between the government and the Democrats is the idea of an inquiry.
—A sleazy deal.
—A sleazy deal indeed. I point out to the House that on 19 October Labor called for an independent tax review for charities. So, if the Democrats are serious about the inquiry that they suggested this afternoon, they should do it. We will support them. We indicated that back on 19 October. We stand ready to have an inquiry into the impact of the GST on the charitable and non-profit sectors. If the Democrats are fair dinkum about their inquiry, they will join Labor in ensuring that such an inquiry takes place.
I have been reminded of the hour by one of my colleagues—probably acting on behalf of many colleagues; it is a sad reflection that I am able to be done over by one—and, in light of that, I will conclude my remarks here. But it is clear that this will not solve the problems. They will continue to haunt this government as the charitable and not-for-profit sector recognises in the months and years ahead just how the GST will impact on them.
debate_title: <title>A NEW TAX SYSTEM (INDIRECT TAX AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1999</title>

name: Swan, Wayne, MP
text:
—These amendments are like rotten fruit: they are shiny on the outside and rotten on the inside. Nothing announced today in the coalition-Democrat deal on charities changes the fact that all charities are to become tax collectors for the Howard government. Their fundraising activities will still be hit by the GST. They are caught coming and going. It does not matter whether they are under $100,000 or over $100,000, they will all become tax collectors for the Howard government. They are the front-line tax collectors for the Howard government. The Howard government is taxing compassion and it is taxing the volunteers. These amendments will not ease the burden on the charitable sector of Australia.

name: Cox, David, MP
text:
—On 30 November, the Howard government released the Downstream Petroleum Products Action Agenda. It was prepared by the minister's department and the oil industry. It has only one objective: to make the case for mergers in the oil refinery industry, which will be supported by the government on a case-by-case basis. It follows two decisions this year by the ACCC not to approve joint ventures between the oil majors because they would lead to less competition and had not been justified as being in the public interest.
The refining industry does face a number of serious short-term and long-term problems but these should have been addressed through a full public inquiry. The government did not obtain an independent report for this policy review, in their case such as from the Productivity Commission. Instead, they managed the process to produce the outcome the oil industry wanted. The result is a report setting out the problems the industry faces and suggesting that the solutions have more to do with mergers than investment.
The industry's objectives and the ACCC public interest test are in direct conflict. The ACCC's public benefit test guidelines say:
Economic development, eg in natural resources, through encouragement of exploration, research and capital investment—
whereas the oil industry's eight-point plan for getting benefit from joint ventures says the opposite:
Improved `capital efficiency' by reducing future investment requirements, eg, for clean fuels, through the ability to make the best use of each refinery's capabilities and existing hardware—
An option canvassed in the report to `invest for 500ppm sulphur diesel now, if the investment will pay prior to the mandated requirement for 50ppm sulphur diesel, and close the refinery prior to 31/12/2005' when the higher standard becomes effective shows the risk Australia faces from this flawed policy process.
The oil majors must be made to accept that there has to be significant investment, not just in clean fuels but also with the objective of having an internationally competitive refining industry in Australia. Long-term policies should not be driven by short-term price pressures resulting from availability of cheap imported fuel because of the Asian crisis. If the oil majors are permitted to replace local refining capacity with imported product, there will be less competition and they will be able to raise prices on both imported and local fuels. It is not just the loss of local jobs and investment. Ultimately, it will be the motorist and Australian business that will pay.	I am concerned the report dismisses restricting merger proposals to exclude `outlier' refineries like Port Stanvac, because that would reduce the benefits obtained by the companies.
South Australia needs a full range of refinery facilities. These facilities are at risk. The technical and commercial issues to keep them open should be dealt with now, not after a merger proposal is approved. Port Stanvac's work force is doing everything it can to make the refinery internationally competitive. They deserve much more than the government's active 
 participation in the loss of their livelihoods. Australia needs an internationally competitive refining industry that will invest in this country's future. The ACCC must withstand government pressure to interpret the public interest test in the light of this report.

name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
text:
—I move:
That the bill be now read a second time. 

This bill provides for the extension of the current statutory self-regulation framework of the migration advice industry until March 2003 and includes several measures to enhance its effectiveness.
In 1997 the government decided to move the migration advice industry to self-regulation through a period of statutory self-regulation.
The government agreed to consider a further move to voluntary self-regulation at the end of two years.
Statutory self-regulation is subject to a sunset clause and ceases to operate on 21 March 2000. The government was therefore committed to reviewing the effectiveness of the operation of statutory self-regulation before that date.
The government has now reviewed the operation of the current arrangements to decide on the most appropriate regulatory model for the migration advice industry beyond March 2000.
The government has found that the industry is not yet ready to move to voluntary self-regulation in view of continuing significant consumer protection concerns, national interest issues and the special nature of the migration advice industry.
In particular, the government has significant concerns about the vulnerability of the client group to exploitation and the ethics and conduct of a small group in the industry.
Given the vulnerability of clients and the potential for malpractice in the industry, it is clear that voluntary regulation of the industry would not be desirable or viable at this stage and that statutory self-regulation should continue.
The review confirmed the appropriateness of the government's decision to introduce the existing statutory self-regulation framework.
The review found that the MIA—that is, the Migration Institute of Australia—acting as the Migration Agents Registration Authority (the MARA) has demonstrated its commitment to the objectives of consumer protection and its capacity to undertake industry regulation.
The MIA, acting as the MARA, has already established sound disciplinary and mediation processes that should continue to increase consumer protection, competence and ethical standards in the industry.
The review of statutory self-regulation was undertaken by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and steered by an independent reference group.
A number of members of the reference group had assisted the government in the 1997 review of the industry.
As in 1997, the most recent reference group was chaired by Mr Ian Spicer, former President of the Confederation of Australian Industry.
The reference group included individuals with a broad understanding of the industry.
In particular:
	 one member was nominated by the MIA;
	 another member had considerable knowledge of community concerns; and
	 a further member was formerly a Minister for Immigration—that is, the Hon John Hodges.
The review gave careful consideration to the performance of the existing arrangements and sought input from over 40 stakeholders.
Particular consideration was given to the views expressed by the industry body.
In its role as the MARA, the MIA has indicated its strong support for the measures included in this bill.
In extending statutory self-regulation, the government has recognised the achievements of the MARA in establishing the self-regulation framework.
All stakeholders have expressed support for the continuation of the existing statutory self-regulation framework at this stage of industry development.
In deciding that it is not yet time to move to voluntary self-regulation, the government has taken account of the fact that the industry is at an early stage of maturity and there is only limited experience with the current arrangements.
Statutory self-regulation has been in place for fewer than 18 months. Some major elements, such as the continuing professional development requirements, have been in place for fewer than 6 months.
While the MIA's coverage of the industry has expanded substantially since statutory self-regulation was introduced and has continued to increase over the last few months, there are still only 30 per cent of registered agents who are members of the MIA.
This would not be sufficient to support a move to voluntary self-regulation when current arrangements expire in March 2000.
There will be another review of the industry in two to three years to re-examine the state of the industry and gauge its progress.
I would expect that at that time it will be possible to assess how far the industry can develop and how well it can sustain voluntary self regulation.
The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will be setting milestones in conjunction with the MARA to monitor the development of the industry in relation to:
.	 improvements in competence and ethical standards;
.	 the extent of MIA industry coverage and its performance in the industry regulation role; and
.	 changes to consumer awareness that would support a less regulated environment.
The extension of statutory self-regulation until March 2003 will provide an opportunity for some of the important industry values being promoted by the MIA and the MARA to be more firmly entrenched in industry practice.
Many industry stakeholders have confirmed, to the review, the need for continued improvements in the ethical standards and competence in the industry and protection available to consumers.
This bill includes two new measures to this end. Other measures will be addressed through amendments which require more complex drafting, which I expect to introduce next year, and through regulation amendments.
The bill includes amendments to make publication requirements relating to decisions by the MARA to cancel or suspend an agent's registration more cost-effective.
Currently the MARA is required to publish full details of any decisions to cancel or suspend an agent's registration in the Saturday edition of a national daily publication, including the evidence for its decisions and its findings on any material details of fact.
Although the intentions behind this requirement are to protect existing and potential clients and to promote agent and community understanding of appropriate ethical standards in the industry, in practice, the requirement has resulted in costly advertisements swamped by excessive detail, with little visual impact and little communicative value.
The amendments in this bill maintain the basic requirements that the MARA should publish its decisions to suspend or cancel an agent's registration and the grounds for its decisions in prescribed publications.
However, the MARA will no longer be required to publish full details of the evidence and its findings on material facts relevant to the decision, saving money for the industry body and thus ultimately agents and consumers.
The amendments will also give the MARA the discretionary power to publish some or all of this detailed information about cancellation or suspension decisions in an expanded variety of formats and methods of publication relevant to its target audiences, including on the Internet and in specialist newspapers.
The amendments will also give protection to other persons publishing in good faith a copy or fair summary of the MARA's decisions.
Together, these amendments will mean that the MARA will be able to use appropriate channels to communicate more effectively—to clients, agents and the general community—its decisions to suspend or cancel an agent's registration.
This bill also provides the MARA with powers to ensure that clients of inactive and deceased agents are not unduly disadvantaged by the agent becoming inactive or as a result of the death of the agent.
Therefore, the MARA will be able to require certain agents—for example, those whose registration has been suspended or cancelled—to provide copies of relevant client documents to the MARA for forwarding to clients.
This will enable clients to continue their cases with another agent or to manage their cases themselves, ensuring that critical deadlines in relation to a client's visa applications or reviews of applications are not ignored.
The MARA's ability to do this will be discretionary. There may be cases such as multi-agent practices in which the MARA does not need to intervene.
However, the relevance of this power was highlighted by the recent closure of the largest migration advice firm in Australia.
Fortunately, this company voluntarily made files available to the MARA.
However, if such a situation occurs after the commencement of the bill, and if the firm or agent does not make files available to the MARA voluntarily, the powers in this bill will provide a basis for the MARA to require that relevant documents be copied, and that those copies be given to clients.
The closure of this particular migration agency is being closely evaluated by my Department and the MARA to identify any further issues which may need to be addressed within the industry regulation arrangements.
In conclusion, this bill extends the protection that is available to consumers under the current arrangements and will continue the progress that has been achieved in the last 18 months towards enhancing competence and ethical standards in the industry.
I commend this bill to the Main Committee. I present the explanatory memorandum.

name: Sciacca, Con, MP
text:
—It is Christmas time, so I will not speak for long and I will be very nice to the minister this morning. The Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1999  is another bill—amongst just about every one that has come up for debate in either this or any other chamber—that we have supported. We support the sunset clause being extended until March 2003. I have had the opportunity on a number of occasions to talk to the industry association, and I am quite convinced that they are doing everything they can to ensure that the migration advice industry is cleaned up as best it can be.
I am aware that, from time to time, there is a lot of public concern, and I am sure that my colleague the honourable member for Chifley will say later that there are always complaints about shonky migration agents which come to members of parliament. In most cases—probably in every case—they are not registered and are not fair dinkum. We need to make sure that justice is seen to be done and that appropriate consumer regulations and mechanisms are in place to protect what are most often people who cannot speak the language, do not know our systems and are very easily conned into handing over money for something that, in many cases, is of no value to them.
This bill simply extends the current arrangements for the regulation of the migration advice industry. It also amends the Migration Act to provide more efficient methods of warning the public of the suspension or cancellation of an agent's registration and enables the Migration Agents Registration Authority to protect the rights and interests of people whose migration agent has died or has been deregistered.
I recently went to one of MARA's conferences in Brisbane, I think, and I was quite impressed with their education schemes for making some of their registered migration agents aware of what it is that they are supposed to do. I noticed that something like 40 per cent of all registered migration agents are lawyers. That is a problem in the sense that lawyers do not particularly want to be part of any industry body but their own. In this case, it really is an important facet of the migration advice industry that everybody should be involved in a whole group. To be truthful, I do not see why they do not join the industry association because the industry association are the ones that in effect form MARA under this legislation and, if you want to be a migration agent, you come under that umbrella as well.
I noticed that something like 38 per cent of complaints received by MARA concerned lawyers, although it does not appear that MARA referred any of these complaints to a disciplinary body for lawyers. It is a bit hard for a disciplinary body of lawyers to make some sort of value judgment as to whether someone in the migration area has made a mistake or done the wrong thing. That is something the immigration minister might be prepared to look at. He will get support from me on that for sure.
The opposition supports this bill. We thank the minister and those in the minister's office for the extra information they gave to Senator Cooney and Senator McKiernan, who were quite interested in knowing some of the details of the review. I have had a good look at the review, and I think it has been very wide ranging. It has come up with a number of better initiatives for making this system work better. Given that this self-regulatory scheme has been in place for only a year, it is sensible that we extend it for a few more years. I noticed as well that it will be reviewed again during the next three years. I do not propose to say anything more about this. It is a measure that the opposition welcomes.
In conclusion, all my dealings with the industry association have been good. They are always willing to talk to me and, I am sure, other members of parliament as well. I think that migration agents do not deserve to have the reputation now that they have had in the past. Yes, there are some shonks still around and, yes, I am concerned that only 24 per cent of registered migration agents are actually part of the industry body. It is the industry body that are looking at further education and the development of expertise, so they might want to redouble their efforts in that regard. But, given that they have only been travelling for a year, I think we can give them another three years and then review them again to see how they are going. I will leave it at that and  remind the minister again that, on the last day we are here, we are again in a bipartisan mode.

name: Baird, Bruce, MP
text:
—It is my pleasure to rise to support the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1999  today and to commend the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs for bringing it forward. The minister has proved himself to be a very capable and effective minister in managing a fairly difficult portfolio, not the least of which has involved the events that have emerged over the last several years and, more particularly, in the last couple of months. This is part of an effective administration that, for the most part, has received bipartisan support. I think that is an appropriate way to go. It is difficult to manage at the best of times. There are lots of international sensitivities. I was very pleased to note that the shadow minister for immigration, the honourable member for Bowman, also supported the bill today. It is good to see such bipartisan bonhomie and Christmas spirit at this time.
In terms of the provisions of the legislation, it is appropriate that the sunset clause be extended for a further three years and that the voluntary code which has been in existence be given time to operate and to show its effectiveness. There is no doubt that the management of migration agents is a difficult area. In the past, in the area of migration agents, as the shadow minister said, there has been a tendency for a lot of shonks to operate. People have been encouraged to use every trick in the book in order to stay here.
During our inquiry into the treatment of refugees, there was an open admission by a lot of the people who were dealing with refugees that some of the agents clearly did not have ethical standards. This piece of legislation is about standards in the industry. It is about ensuring appropriate supervision of agents. It also provides the ability to take away the registration of agents where they have demonstrated unethical behaviour. It is not in the interests of those migrants who come here or those who are going through the process of applying for citizenship or migration to this country to be fooled in terms of the appropriate channels or requirements.
There are four registered migration agents operating in my electorate of Cook. Jian Wang and Ying Feng Lui operate from the suburb of Miranda, and John Shanahan and Bobby Halim are based in Sylvania. These agents assist friends and family members of my constituents who need advice concerning visa categories for relatives' applications, and also asylum seekers wanting assistance in putting their claim together.
The operations of these agencies are assisted and overseen by MARA, the Migration Agents Registration Authority. Since March 1998, when the minister appointed the Migration Institute of Australia to act as the Migration Agents Registration Authority, it has performed well in ensuring that migration agents have served their clients well. Minister, seeing that you are in the chamber, it is appropriate to congratulate you on taking that step in terms of registration. It is also appropriate that we would want to see more of the agents belonging to the 
 association. That is the appropriate way to go if they want to undertake the necessary training that is available to them.
MARA has focused on the ongoing education of agents, not on exercising coercive punishments such as by imposing fines or other penalties. The ultimate sanction is that their registration is taken away. It is similar in many ways to the situation involving travel agents, where a self-regulating authority is in place and where deregistration can occur. The authority has managed entry into the group of registered agents, their re-registration, the fielding of complaints, the initiation of disciplinary proceedings, and generally the maintenance of industry standards.
The role of MARA is set out in section 316 of the Migration Act. It produces an annual report and has a code of conduct. It also produces newsletters for members and continuing professional development kits and mediation kits, and runs a web site for which it provides fact sheets.
During the last 12 months the authority has held eight mediations. The authority believes that the mediations are an overall success enabling the parties themselves to establish an agreement to their dispute. Of the eight mediations held to date, five achieved an agreement to which both parties adhered. From these five successfully mediated agreements, five have resulted in the authority deciding to take no further action on the complaint.
This bill has certainly enhanced the authority's power in regulating the industry. It allows for the better warning of clients and migration agents by indicating a particular agency's standing within the group, overseen by MARA, and by providing information on whether an agent is fully accredited. It safeguards the rights of clients of deregistered or deceased agents.
In August 1999, over 3,000 people were left unrepresented in their applications to the department of immigration and appeal bodies for various classes of visas when Barlow and Co. went out of business. Obviously they had spent a lot of money in the process of their claims and paid it to Barlow. Suddenly Barlow went out of existence and all assistance that had been given in the past just went for nought through the business collapse of this organisation.
In response, this bill contains measures designed to ensure that people whose migration agent has been deregistered will be able to continue with their migration or review applications without disadvantage, and I think that is a significant step forward. There may be further amendments to part 3 of the Migration Act in response to this collapse and these amendments will be included in an omnibus bill at a later date. In summary, I commend the minister for bringing forward this legislation. It is appropriate that we continue the close supervision of agents. This voluntary code is appearing to work. We would encourage more agents to belong to the association to get all the benefits of the training and newsletters et cetera. It is good to see such bipartisan agreement on such an important part of migration activities in this country.

name: Price, Roger, MP
text:
—I notice that the Christmas spirit has been referred to. I hope honourable members do not think I am a heathen by virtue of my contribution. I certainly do support this bill but I would be less than honest if I did not say that I do have quite a number of reservations about the activities of migration agents. Very briefly, in 1997 the government commenced statutory self-regulation of the migration advice industry and appointed the Migration Agents Registration Authority, MARA, to establish a regulatory body for the industry with the aim to eventually move towards self-regulation.
The bill expands the Migration Agents Registration Authority's powers to access files where the registration of a migration agent is cancelled or suspended; where the agent has become incapacitated, dies or is voluntarily deregistered; or where a migration agent's registration expires; and to provide copies of relevant documents to clients. This will, of course, maintain and strengthen consumer protection and contribute to the integrity of the migration and humanitarian programs by promoting an ethical and competent migration advice industry. 	I certainly think that this is a very worthy objective, but I think the agents risk their industry if they fail to rigorously ensure that they have an ethical industry, including the self-regulatory body MARA.
It is important to recognise that currently MARA has  jurisdiction only over registered migration agents. In the majority of cases the only disciplinary sanction that MARA has against a registered migration agent is to cancel or suspend their registration. Once an agent is deregistered, he or she is no longer within the jurisdiction of MARA.
As the shadow minister has already mentioned, 40 per cent of migration agents in 1998 were lawyers and 38 per cent of the complaints arose from those agents. It seems to me to be absolutely absurd that a solicitor acting as a solicitor can be disciplined by his professional body for errors or whatever, but, notwithstanding the fact that MARA has the power to refer these matters to the legal disciplinary bodies, no referrals have occurred to date in relation to acting as a migration agent. I make this point: from my experience of the constituents that come through my front door, I do not see that they are less exploited by migration agents who happen to be solicitors than by the ones that are not solicitors. I think this is a blight on the legal profession and it is a real weakness. I do not think a solicitor should be secure in his legal profession irrespective of what he does as a migration agent. That is completely abhorrent to me and I think it is abhorrent to any sense of fairness and any sense of justice.
The honourable member for Cook, who made a contribution to this debate, referred again to the case of Barlow and Co., Australia's largest legal practice specialising in migration, which collapsed. They had some 3,000 clients on their books, some from my electorate. If a firm of solicitors collapses and they have moneys in their care on behalf of clients, that money is protected. If a legal practice that wholly or partly practises in migration law collapses, why should the migration clients of that practice not be indemnified as well? I would be very interested, as I always am, to hear what the minister or the department may have to say about this matter. There are contradictions. If my assertions are wrong in this I am more than happy to be advised otherwise, but I suspect they are not.
I see a lot of people about migration issues in my electorate. In fact, I can say that approximately—and we do keep records of it—80 per cent of the people who walk through my door come to me about migration matters. I will just say this: I have always had a practice in my office of trying to tell them exactly what the honest situation is. Some people would love to hear that miracles can be done or that, through the intervention of their federal member, we will be able to ensure that they stay here. There have been some exceptional cases, and I would be less than gracious if I did not acknowledge the fact that the department has always bent over backwards to assist me in those cases. But when people want to apply for a refugee status or a protection visa and we know that they have absolutely no basis for sustaining it, then we tell them so.
Indeed, I came from the old school which said it was never a backbencher's responsibility to say no, it was the minister's. I have changed that in terms of migration—we are now no 
 longer sending on requests for ministerial discretion when we are more than confident that it will not be exercised. In fact, we tell constituents now that we will not deal with their case when they are being handled by a migration agent.
Sometimes people come here on a visitor's visa, stay for a while and find that they love Australia. They have been reunited with some relatives or they see the marvellous opportunities here, and they want to apply to become permanent residents. I am quite convinced they would make excellent citizens, but they cannot apply. So they go to a business migration agent, who will probably get them to apply for a protection visa. If the protection visa is not approved, there is an opportunity then to appeal to the Refugee Review Tribunal, then the Federal Court or, indeed, to seek exercise of the minister's discretion. That will take about two years and will also take up several thousand dollars.
This is what really upsets me about migration agents. The point I want to make is that the migration agents that act this way do so totally dishonestly. The only way it can be justified is if the client says, `Can you leave me here for two years? I am prepared to pay several thousand dollars for that privilege,' and the migration agent replies, `I will exercise every option available to you but in the knowledge that you will never succeed.' But of course that is not what they are told and that is not the way they apply.
I really resent it if, when every option has been exercised, the migration agent sends them off to my office to ask me then to make representations. Perhaps, Mr Deputy Speaker, coming from Tasmania you do not have so much experience with it—
—I do.
—That is interesting. These people, I feel, in the main are very vulnerable. I am intensely proud to have in my electorate a lot of Filipinos—the largest concentration in any LGA—and also Indians, Pakistanis, Fijians and Lebanese. All these groups of migrants tend to get awfully exploited. They make a wonderful contribution not only to my electorate but also to this nation, but they are being exploited by migration agents, in my humble opinion.
Essentially, when the system of migration agents was first established, the idea was that people could go to them for a reasonable fee and get some advice or assistance in filling in a form and lodging it with the department. That is an appropriate role. But I do not think it is appropriate that the stricter migration guidelines in this country are used to exploit people, to extract money from them by way of fees in the knowledge that their case is absolutely hopeless. I am not suggesting that for us to tighten up in this area is easy, but everyone in this game has a vested interest in a much cleaner system of migration agents and would benefit from it.
I turn now to my last complaint. Let us remember that 40 per cent of migration agents are lawyers. There is a schedule of fees that a solicitor or a barrister can charge. I think that the disciplinary body would not be too happy, for example, with a charge of $500 for one letter. Yet, by and large, when solicitors practise as migration agents there appears to be no control whatsoever over the fees that they can charge for certain actions. Again it is a case of double standards. If someone is legally qualified, the overwhelming disciplinary mantle should be that of the legal profession. I would suggest to the legal profession that it is outrageous that a solicitor can be disciplined for some of his charges when acting in the law other than in migration, but when acting as a migration agent he is allowed to charge—without penalty, without review, without discipline—whatever he likes.
To summarise: the opposition is supporting this measure. In my own electorate I have quite some experience of migration agents. Just this year we have changed some of our practices, after a number of years, in response to problems with migration agents. I would like to see the continuation of migration agents but there is a desperate need for even tougher measures. In particular, it is necessary to get away from the double standards that apply to members of the legal profession when they act as migration agents.

name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
text:
—in reply—I would like first to thank my colleagues for their support for the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1999 . It would be of grave concern to me were the sunset clause to operate and the existing arrangements that we have for supervision to fall. I do want to thank the member for Bowman, as well as the members for Cook and Chifley, for their support for the legislation.
I will not repeat the comments I made in the second reading speech—they stand as printed—but I particularly want the member for Chifley to know that I share many of the concerns he raised. Let me just say that. I and the shadow minister are both members of the legal profession.
—I was gracious enough not to mention that!
—Quite frankly, I emphasise from time to time, and I will do it here, that the legal profession has certain values, ethics. I can see one of my colleagues over there who has even taught law. Some of those ethics that I was taught when I was a young practitioner involved not only my obligation to my client, but also my obligation to fellow practitioners and to the court.
I often say when I speak to migration agents, because there is no court that applies to them, that there is a wider obligation they have to the community of which they are a part that requires some cognisance of the broader national interest. That means that you have a migration program which operates with integrity, a program in which you do not set out to find ways and means to undermine it. I have to say that I think—and members will know that I hold this view very strongly—that there are some who have no cognisance of the wider national interest. If they see a loophole, they believe it is there to be exploited, regardless of its impact.
I have to say that I am very much aware of some of the unconscionable charging arrangements that some members of the profession are involved in. I want members of this committee to know that I have personally raised matters with the Law Society of New South Wales relating to the conduct of members of the legal profession. I have not waited for them to be considered by MARA. I believe that they were of sufficient concern that a representative body of the profession ought to have been active in taking them up.
Members will know—and this relates to the comments from the member for Chifley—that not all migration agents are involved in the practice of misleading their clients. Sometimes they tell them, because the client comes in simply wanting a work opportunity, that by using the system they can get them a year or two. Some advertisements, of some members of the profession, for people to come forward who have exhausted all other remedies—even been to other agents—say, `If you come and see me you can join my class action, which I have under way right now, which will enable you to apply lawfully for another bridging visa.'
Members may not know the background reasons for why bridging visas have to operate as they do. It is a very simple reason: we have detention facilities normally for about 900 people 
 in Australia. If we were to arrest and hold every unlawful that we located and everybody involved in legal proceedings or making applications to me or using the tribunal processes, we would have to have detention facilities for 10,000 people. Bridging visas are not issued to enable people to go out and get work. They are issued for a very practical reason: that is, unless we have some basis upon which they can be held in the community while they undertake their lawful entitlements, we cannot properly detain them. That is the only alternative that remains available to us.
Why did I raise another matter with the Law Society of New South Wales? I came across a letter that had been written by a solicitor who had initiated a class action on behalf of clients. All of the class actions that we have had to date have failed. There are some that are still before the courts, but all of those where we have had a judicial decision taken have failed. The letter I saw in this case from a member of the legal profession was to the clients of a failed class action, encouraging them to send another $250 so that they could be part of an appeal. I guess that is not unreasonable. When the solicitor then says that, in addition, there will be no accounting for the money that is paid by the client and, further, there will be no refund of any of the money paid, I consider that highly unethical. I guess I was right because the Law Society counselled the solicitor. He was told to tell the client that he would account for the money.
There are problems associated with running an administrative scheme, and MARA is in a difficult position. They are in the same position that we face in relation to any of the so-called rights that people have, such as the right to practise. If we are going to take away somebody's livelihood, there has to be evidence. The reason we cannot act against half the shonks is that they cover their tracks so carefully. The people involved, particularly if their actions have failed, may have been removed from Australia. The prospect of getting evidence against some of these people is extremely difficult. Somebody might say, `Try to push the envelope.' You push the envelope and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act operates. They are back off to the courts.
This supervision really involves the protection of shonks. The difficulty we have is that there is not a ready appreciation in this field that ethics are required. Every time I go to the MIA—they are almost sick of me coming through the door—I tell them that we need ethical standards. You have to have an appreciation that in this field there is a wider Australian public interest.
I think it is important in discussing these issues for people to know that there is a will on the part of the government to do something about it. I will look for any creative ideas to enable us to do it more effectively. I am sure, as the honourable member for Bowman indicated in his remarks, that there will be support from the agents who are ethical. I am sure there is a desire on the part of the MIA to deal with these matters, but, as has been said, when 70 per cent of the industry do not bother to join the industry body and you get the ethical people in it and the others outside, the task is fairly difficult.
I want to conclude by saying that I appreciated the compliments paid to me by the member for Cook, and I thank him for that. But I particularly want to thank the member for Chifley, not because he is lightening the load in my office but because I think the approach that he is taking is absolutely right. It is the approach I took as a backbencher in not misleading people as to the outcomes that can be achieved. I think it is just exploitation of the vulnerable to hold out hope where none exists. Yet we know that the exploitation of the vulnerable is 
 to hold out hope and to take more money off them. A far better approach by disciplinary bodies, including the legal disciplinary bodies, is not in challenging the scheme because it might require solicitors to come in and be a part of it, but ensuring that appropriate standards are met would speak well of the law societies and similar bodies and I think would lift the esteem in which the profession is held in the eyes of the public, where they could be far more proactive. I hope some of my friends in the profession one day have an opportunity to read these remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

name: Stone, Sharman, MP
text:
—I move:
That the bill be now read a second time.
The War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999  repeals section 22 of the War Crimes Act 1945. The act was amended in 1989 prior to the fall of the Iron Curtain to enable trial in Australia with respect to conduct engaged in during World War II in Europe. Although the usual practice would have been to extradite persons accused of such crimes to the country where the crimes occurred, it was considered at the time to be politically unacceptable to extradite persons to countries behind the then so-called Iron Curtain. Some years ago the Iron Curtain fell, fortunately, and many of the republics—including Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania—are now independent states and have been accepted as members of the Council of Europe. Australia has in the past been prepared to enter into extradition arrangements with any country that is a member of the council.
The government is actively pursuing the possibility of establishing modern extradition arrangements with many of these newly independent states. However, even if a modern extradition relationship were in place, it would still be impossible for those countries to comply with an extradition request while section 22 of the War Crimes Act remains in force in our country. Effectively, section 22 of the act provides that, where a person's extradition from Australia is sought for conduct covered by the act, no surrender for extradition is possible unless the requesting country establishes a prima facie case. Thus, notwithstanding a modern extradition relationship with these countries, if the offence for which the extradition sought is a war crime, then the requesting state must provide a prima facie case.
Because of the differences between civil code and common law countries, the practical effect is that it would be virtually impossible for a civil code jurisdiction to successfully seek the extradition of a person suspected of a war crime. The concept of a prima facie case is determining sufficiency of evidence, and it is one to which most common law countries are accustomed. However, those countries which operate under a civil code system—for example, Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania—do not use this test in criminal proceedings. The practical issue is that the laws of evidence in common law systems are such as to make it very difficult for a civil code jurisdiction to supply evidence in an admissible form.
The repeal of section 22 will remove the fundamental barrier to Australia's cooperation with the international community in relation to suspected war criminals.
This is not to say that extradition of a suspected war criminal would be automatic. Any requests for the extradition of a suspected war criminal would be subject to the general extradition arrangement with the requesting country. Such arrangement must include all the usual safeguards spelt out in the Extradition Act 1988. All that the amendment will do is to remove an additional onerous requirement that relates only to the extradition of war criminals. This government sees no reason in principle why this practical impediment to the extradition of war criminals should be retained.
The amendment to the act will not have any financial impact. I commend the bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill to this committee.

name: Kerr, Duncan, MP
text:
—The opposition supports this legislation, the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 . By way of background, it is useful to put ourselves back into the frame of mind that existed at the time the provisions relating to extradition of alleged war criminals from the Second World War were enacted. It was a period where the world was convulsed with outrage in relation to the atrocities that had been conducted in Germany and in the countries that Germany had occupied—the forced deportation of many millions of people and the extermination of millions in the gas chambers of the Nazi war machine. There was a sense that the world had to enact a framework that would deal with those who had perpetrated such atrocities.
Nonetheless, there was another mind-set that also applied and that was a fundamental distrust of the legal regimes of many Eastern European states. That was because, at that time, those states were part of the larger empire of the Soviet Union or certainly subject to their dominion. It was a widely held view that those regimes were prone to distort historical records and that their legal systems provided no framework that was adequate for this country to respect in relation to those charged with criminal or quasi-political offences of this nature. I only say quasi-political in the sense that they arose out of the conflagration of war.
