The Soviet regime, having itself lost, I think, something in the order of 20 million dead as a result of resisting a German invasion, was felt to have such an antipathy to those who might be charged with offences that the normal protections of the legal system could not be guaranteed.
In the Cold War climate that I grew up in as a young man, there was still the lasting aftermath of a campaign in Australia to have the Communist Party of Australia proscribed as an illegal organisation and a widely held view that it would have been improper for us to send back to Eastern European countries persons against whom charges even of this nature were made to face trial and the penalties that would have applied in those eastern bloc countries, unless we ourselves formed a view that there was a substantial and probably conclusive case against them.
That was the framework in which the extradition provisions that currently apply were made, which require, before a surrender to another country of a person against whom extradition is sought for these offences, that an Australian tribunal must first satisfy itself in relation to the prima facie case that exists against that person. That is a not insubstantial hurdle when we are dealing with very different legal regimes. It is not an insubstantial hurdle even when we are dealing with similar legal regimes that understand a common law system of what actually comprises a prima facie case. But when we are dealing with civil law countries—and most of Europe does operate on a civil law environment—the knowledge base to put together 
 effectively an application for extradition is limited. That has been in part the root reason why, in the law of extradition generally, we have moved away from the requirement for the establishment of a prima facie case.
There is a hold-over in this area which still remains on the statute books. It is now thought appropriate to, in a sense, align the provisions that relate to extradition for the general run of criminal offences with those that we will now be enacting with respect to alleged war crimes. That will facilitate more readily the surrender to countries which were formerly part of the Soviet bloc, including Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, of persons who are asserted by those jurisdictions to be in Australia, if any such assertion is made, and against whom they assert evidence is available to establish proof of guilt in relation to atrocities that occurred during the Second World War.
My briefing to date from the department is that no intention to file an extradition application currently stands. But it may well be that, over time, these provisions are exercised. I know that my colleague from Melbourne Ports has put questions on the Notice Paper in relation to a Mr Ozols and he has raised this matter with me. It may well be that the authorities in the country where he is alleged to have been a significant and senior participant in a number of atrocities may feel it appropriate to seek such extradition. There may be others. By changing the law in this manner we do facilitate that.
There are always arguments that ought to be taken seriously with respect to those who have come to Australia after World War II that amongst those persons were some who were not seeking to make a new home in Australia as a result of circumstances which we would all regard as perfectly understandable and justifiable but who, it is asserted, had been involved in these atrocities. In those circumstances, I think the whole Australian community would want to see those persons brought to justice, whether in this country or overseas.
Of course, when we did have the regime that formerly applied—that is, the prima facie regime—when the former Labor government came to office and was confronted with substantial allegations that there were persons living amongst the Australian community who had been involved with these events, the response that was then made was to establish a special investigation unit which was resourced to assess those matters and to prepare them for prosecution. A number of prosecutions did take place.
For a variety of reasons the basis upon which the SIU was established was that, rather than facilitate extradition, the trials should take place in Australia. That, in itself, gave rise to a whole series of complexities. Perhaps that was a bad decision, in retrospect. It is easy to be wise in hindsight, but perhaps it was a bad decision because of the difficulties in bringing witnesses to Australia and in establishing proof of materials held on files in those countries which were then still subject to Soviet domination.
A whole range of other such issues did make those trials particularly difficult and, as history will show, either acquittals or discharges for reasons of ill health or the age of the accused meant that we obtained no convictions. I must say that I do not think that outcome has stilled the disquiet amongst those who suffered at the hands of the Nazi war machine. Perhaps there are still some living amongst us in this community who should be better placed on trial and account to history for the actions they undertook.
The opposition is content to support these changes. We accept that the international legal circumstances in respect of both the former Soviet Union and the states which were subject to it have changed and that we should apply the same regime to those extraditions as apply 
 in other areas. That is not to say that somebody charged with an extraditable offence is entirely without some opportunity for an examination of the matters alleged against them. There are a series of processes, often much litigated already in this country, where people are made subject to extradition requests. The extradition requests are subject to a range of discretionary matters in the end which the minister must consider before a surrender is made.
So it is not as if a case cannot be made either administratively or later at a political level to the minister that a surrender request must be acceded to if there are some circumstances wherein it is asserted that the legal regime in those countries is still not appropriate to enable a fair trial. There may indeed be some argument advanced to that effect in respect of particular matters. Nonetheless, I think the generality of this legislation is now most appropriate, and it indeed fits with the way in which the international community has seen appropriate to regard extradition and, as importantly, reflects the continuing abhorrence by the Australian community of the Holocaust and those who gave rise to it.
With those remarks, I indicate that the opposition does support this legislation. As I said, there are many things that perhaps with hindsight we might reflect on in relation to the conduct of matters previously. But it is not an area where I am content to say, as some amongst the Australian community do, that these are events in the dim, distant past which should be allowed to fade from memory. To the extent that properly based evidence is available to establish the fact of willed participation in these terrible events, I do not believe we, as a parliament, should ever stand in the way of the proper trial and punishment of such persons.

name: Georgiou, Petro, MP
text:
—The War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999  provides for the repeal of section 22 of the War Crimes Act. The effect of the repeal of the legislation will be to facilitate extradition proceedings of suspected World War II war criminals residing in Australia to countries with civil legal codes and, in particular, to former Soviet bloc countries. The bill will bring the evidentiary requirements for the extradition of suspected war criminals into line with those of other criminal offences in Australia, subject to the Extradition Act 1988.
Section 22 of the War Crimes Act was originally introduced in response to concerns over judicial processes in the former Warsaw Pact countries. Prior to the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War, there were concerns that individuals who faced extradition to countries in the Eastern bloc would not be subjected to the same judicial standards that could be expected in the West. As a result, an additional requirement to establish a prima facie case in the Australian courts prior to successful extradition of alleged war criminals was introduced. While the prima facie requirement was in response to concerns about Soviet bloc countries, it also had the effect of applying to all civil law jurisdictions. A prima facie case is a feature of the judicial system in common law countries and ensures that, at a relatively early stage of proceedings, there is sufficient evidence to establish grounds for a preliminary case against the accused. However, it is not commonly employed in civil law countries and, because of the significant differences in the evidentiary procedures of the two codes, it has been almost impossible in practice for countries with civil codes to extradite suspected war criminals from Australia.
With the end of the Cold War and the breakup of the Soviet empire, judicial processes have considerably improved in what was once the Eastern bloc. The Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, as well as Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, 
 Slovakia, Slovenia, and Russia, have all reformed their legal systems, and their criminal and civil justice systems have met requirements for admission into the Council of Europe.
Australia has, in the past, been prepared to establish extradition arrangements with any country that is a member of the Council of Europe, such as France and Germany. The rationale then for demanding that a higher threshold of guilt be established prior to extradition of suspected war criminals to the Eastern bloc is no longer evident.
Section 22, however, continues to create impediments in establishing extradition arrangements with civil law countries that may have cause to request the extradition of suspected war criminals from the Second World War residing in Australia. The repeal of this provision for extra evidentiary requirements for war criminals prior to extradition will also bring Australia into line with war crime extradition procedures in Europe. Neither Britain nor Western European countries retain additional evidentiary requirements in respect of the extradition of war criminals. As has been referred to, the rights of individuals in Australia facing extradition continue to be safeguarded by the Extradition Act under which the Attorney-General also retains a residual discretion to decline the surrender of a person to a foreign jurisdiction.
The effect then of the legislation will be to remove a significant impediment to the extradition of suspected Nazi war criminals. It is a further attempt to reduce the possibility that Australia should be used as a haven for war criminals or individuals who are suspected of having committed crimes against humanity and are sought by other jurisdictions.
The issue of suspected war criminals residing in our country has received considerable prominence in Australian public debate in the whole period since the Second World War. Indeed, as early as 1947, allegations were made in Australian newspapers that former Nazis and Nazi collaborators had managed to enter Australia.
From the 1950s to the 1970s, law enforcement authorities received a number of reports about individuals suspected of involvement in war crimes during World War II. There were also a number of extradition requests from communist countries. None of these requests were acceded to.
According to the final report of the Special Investigations Unit of the Attorney-General's Department, the US also failed to receive significant assistance from Australia in response to their requests in the course of the eighties. Throughout the 1980s, the Office of Special Investigation of the US Justice Department made a number of requests for assistance with suspected war criminals residing in Australia who were potential witnesses to investigations in the United States.
In 1986, ABC Radio broadcast a series of programs called Nazis in Australia. The series, by journalist Mark Aarons, contained a number of documented serious allegations about suspected Nazi war criminals who had come to Australia since the Second World War. Following Mr Aarons's revelations, the Australian government appointed Mr Andrew Menzies to conduct a review of allegations relating to the presence of Nazi war criminals in Australia. Mr Menzies found that it was more likely than not that a significant number of persons who committed serious war crimes did enter Australia and that appropriate further action needed to be taken.
As a result of the Menzies finding, the government amended the War Crimes Act to enable war crimes to be dealt with in Australian courts. An investigative unit, to be known as the Special Investigations Unit or SIU, of the Attorney-General's Department was established 
 under the direction of Mr Robert Greenwood QC. The SIU operated from 1987 to 1992. During that period it conducted 841 investigations into suspected war criminals residing in Australia. Of the 841 investigations, 819 were suspended due to a number of factors, including that the suspects were found to have been deceased, living abroad or unfit to stand trial. In other cases, investigators were unable to substantiate the allegations, there was insufficient evidence and in some cases the accused had been previously convicted abroad.
There were, however, four cases that were referred to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. Three of these cases went to trial. Two were unsuccessful, a third was abandoned on medical grounds and, in 1992, the SIU was closed down by the Labor government before charges could be laid against the fourth suspect. In 1995, Robert Greenwood, the former director of the SIU, launched a strong attack on the then government, accusing it of actively frustrating and undermining the operation of the SIU.
It is interesting that the then Labor finance minister, Peter Walsh, in his autobiography, Confessions of a failed finance minister, said that, as finance minister, he tried to prevent the establishment of the SIU and hoped that `the crazy exercise would be terminated'. It is instructive that Mr Walsh made this additional claim:
Whatever moral force the argument for the War Crimes bill had, was somewhat diluted by the contemporary behaviour of the Israeli Army in Gaza and the West Bank . . . 
One would hope that former Senator Walsh's views did not play a role in the previous government's decision to close down the SIU.
It did become apparent, however, from the three trials that were conducted, that it is very difficult to successfully prosecute in Australia individuals who are alleged to have committed crimes against humanity in other countries, particularly when those crimes occurred some time ago.
Australia is not the only country to face the challenge of bringing to justice suspected war criminals who have migrated to their country. Both Canada and the US have been confronted with numerous cases of suspected war criminals in their jurisdiction. They have responded to those cases with a variety of measures, including revocation of citizenship and deportation of more than 50 individuals found to have been engaged in crimes against humanity.
In Australia, there is still public concern over suspected war criminals residing here. The most prominent of those persons is a Mr Konrad Kalejs. Mr Kalejs immigrated to Australia in 1950 and gained citizenship in 1957. He travelled to the US soon afterwards and became a successful property developer. In 1984, he was arrested in the US, and deportation proceedings were commenced against him. He is accused by the US Justice Department of having been a senior officer in the Latvian auxiliary security police, a pro-Nazi unit that killed tens of thousands of people during World War II.
In 1994, the US Federal Court of Appeals determined that Mr Kalejs should be deported to Australia. According to the judge, Mr Kalejs was:
. . . a key officer in a unit that killed tens of thousands of innocents. Kalejs and his unit had two other duties besides killing Jews in the Riga ghetto . . . The unit joined the German SS in so-called anti-partisan activity, which was little more than a cover for arresting and murdering civilians.
In 1994, Mr Kalejs was deported to Australia. In 1995, he left Australia for Canada where he was arrested, declared persona non grata, and, in June 1995, returned to Australia.
In September 1995, Kalejs was again arrested at Toronto airport after making a second trip there, and he was detained by authorities until his immigration hearing. On 18 August 1997, a Canadian immigration tribunal ordered Mr Kalejs deported back to Australia and found that he had been `an accomplice to the acts of murder, forcible confinement, enslavement and torture.' The tribunal found that Mr Kalejs had `violated the laws of war and committed war crimes, or crimes against humanity.' The Canadian tribunal also found that Mr Kalejs `was a party to the offences of murder and kidnapping.'
Mr Kalejs was deported back to Australia. The office of the minister for justice has advised that the DPP concluded that the evidence available here is insufficient to launch a successful criminal prosecution against Konrad Kalejs.
In November 1997, Latvia made a mutual assistance request to Australia for documents concerning genocide and war crimes involving Mr Kalejs. I am advised by the minister's office that, following a comprehensive review of relevant departmental files, a considerable amount of documentation on Mr Kalejs was provided to the Latvian authorities in response to their request for assistance. Australia also has had discussions with Latvia and Lithuania with a view to establishing extradition arrangements with those countries.
It is important to note that this legislation is not in response to any one case or individual; rather, it is designed to regularise our extradition arrangements in respect of accused World War II criminals who may be seeking sanctuary in Australia. As the minister has said, this move sends out a strong message internationally that Australia is not, and will not be, a haven for suspected World War II war criminals.
The challenge for our society is to find a way in which we can work with the international community to ensure that principles of justice apply to those involved in crimes against humanity who may seek a safe haven or refuge in Australia. It is a tragic reality of the second half of this century that crimes against humanity, atrocities, war crimes and attempted genocide did not end with the end of the Second World War. Indeed, if we look at Rwanda, Cambodia, the attempted extermination of people in Iraq, and more recently in East Timor, it is apparent that such acts of carnage have not abated as the 20th century draws to a close.
The moral imperative from the extermination of more than six million Jews during World War II was to never forget but, as time draws on, the memory of the international community does drift.
There are some who argue that many of those who were engaged in war crimes during World War II are now old men, that time has moved on and that we should forget the past. There are those who argue that it is too difficult and too costly to bring to justice men who have committed crimes many years ago. Indeed, there are some who even argue that we should not concern ourselves with crimes committed in a foreign land.
But the rule of law is not some fashionable policy from which we can pick and choose. If a man lives in our midst who is responsible for the deaths of one or 30,000 civilians, do we not have a responsibility to see him brought to justice? Can there really be time lines on mass murder? Can we seriously evoke a forgive and forget response to those who have committed crimes against humanity?
Dr Colin Rubenstein, the executive director of the Australia/Israel and Jewish Affairs Council, argues:
. . . neither the passage of time nor vagaries of location should become pretexts for inaction in the pursuit of justice. 

If individuals who reside in this country have committed crimes against humanity in other countries, then we should take every measure possible to assist in bringing those individuals to justice. As Mark Baker, the Melbourne University history academic, has written:
A passport is not a confessional box where one secures absolution from guilt.
In the period following World War II, inadequate vetting procedures created favourable circumstances for suspected war criminals to seek sanctuary in Australia. If a crime can be graduated, it is hard to envision a more heinous crime than that committed by individuals who have been complicit in genocide, the deliberate effort to destroy a national, racial or ethnic population. Future generations will not judge us well if we do not take every measure possible to bring to justice those who have committed crimes against humanity. This bill is an important part of that process. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

name: Danby, Michael, MP
text:
—The War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 , concerning the extradition of war criminals, will be some small consolation to the Australian public and even smaller consolation to those who still suffer with memories of the atrocities committed during World War II, many of whom are my constituents. As has been outlined by the member for Kooyong, there are strong reasons of legal uniformity for supporting this bill, which changes the level of legal proof needed by countries seeking extradition of war criminals from Australia. Bipartisan support for this bill should not lead the government, particularly the Minister for Justice or the Attorney-General, to think that there is approval for what some regard as their inaction in tackling these issues of war crimes since this government has been in office.
In all fairness to this government I would say, however, that it is probably not the only one whose handling of this issue is legally, ethically and politically problematic. Our inaction in Australia is currently affecting our reputation overseas. Only last weekend, the influential US current affairs program 20/20, watched by an estimated 60 million viewers around America and hosted by America's premier current affairs interviewer Barbara Walters, alleged that mass murderers are able to live comfortably in Australia without fear of prosecution, as compared with the United States, which has continued to regularly prosecute and deport Nazi war criminals.
The current government's response to these queries since it has been in office was summed up by the Attorney-General in 1997. Indeed, it was taken up again by the minister for justice in her various media appearances on Monday in response to the 20/20 program. I would sum up their attitude as insouciance and inaction. In my view it is, quite frankly, embarrassing. The minister told the 7.30 Report that she would not look into these matters herself. Rather, in a bureaucratic sidestep, she said that this was a matter for the Australian Federal Police. She knows full well that the Australian Federal Police are under the clear impression that the government does not want this matter raised or prosecutions recommenced.
One gets the impression from the media appearances of the minister for justice that she has kept herself in splendid ignorance of some of these issues: benign neglect, the blind eye to the telescope. At least that is how she came across in her response to the 20/20 program, when Mr O'Brien interviewed her on the 7.30 Report. She was asked whether she supported a past government's decision in 1992 to disband the Special Investigations Unit. The SIU was set up within the Attorney-General's portfolio to investigate and prosecute, under the amended War Crimes Act 1945, any individuals found to be residing in Australia who had committed crimes against humanity during World War II.
We know that the minister for justice was not in government then, but she claims to have been advised that one of the cases that had been put by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, regarded by the unit as its strongest case and above the three cases which had been unsuccessful, did not proceed because the Director of Public Prosecutions decided there was not enough evidence to proceed.
We know that this is simply not true. The minister and the government know that. After three unsuccessful prosecutions, mounting pressure from the then Liberal opposition and growing expenditure, policy fatigue set in. The then government announced that it would close the Special Investigations Unit. With only weeks until the closure of the unit, something of a battle developed between the SIU and the then Attorney-General and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions over the fourth and most significant war crimes case, PU38, involving a gentleman called Karlis Ozols, who has been mentioned a number of times by previous Attorneys, so I am not doing anything unusual in mentioning his name here. Ozols was a volunteer in the SS auxiliary, the Arajs Commando, and still lives peacefully in Melbourne. He should and could have been dealt with by Australia's legislation if the recommendation of senior independent counsel, Mr Peter Faris QC, had been addressed. This is in direct juxtaposition to the minister's ill-advised comments that nothing further could be done on this matter, according to her advice.
On 28 June 1992, Faris concluded his advice to the DPP, estimating that, while some research still needed to be completed, it would take only another three months to have all of the evidence prepared for trial against Ozols, that there was already a prima facie case for mass murder and war crimes. Mr Faris set out a number of charges and advised, `It would be wrong to shut the investigation down. Justice demands the investigation be completed.' The DPP sought to continue the investigation but the then Attorney-General resisted and referred the matter to the Australian Federal Police where the file has remained in a drawer. No prosecution was ever commenced; the investigation was not completed.
In March 1996, of course, the government changed hands and in 1997 a statement by the present Attorney-General, Daryl Williams, announced that the case was concluded and that there was little chance of success in pursuing it to finality. The documentation surrounding Karlis Ozols remained tightly restricted by the Federal Police and the Attorney-General's Department until late 1997. Indeed, the full circumstances surrounding Ozols was never put in the final report of the SIU to parliament.
In June 1992, Faris, the former head of the NCA, had gone through all of the charges, particularly as far as Mr Ozols was concerned. It is interesting to consider the three charges that he specifically put. Let us have a look at some of them. The first was that Mr Ozols was involved in killing people himself, as a lieutenant in the Latvian SD at Maley Trostenets. Mr Faris said there was a prima facie case that Ozols had committed war crimes between July 1942 and 27 September 1943 at Maley Trostenets. The second charge that he suggested there was a prima facie case for advancing was in the Minsk ghetto where, as the commander of the Arajs Commando, Ozols was directly and indirectly responsible for deaths.
Finally, Faris said that between 8 and 9 February 1943, Ozols and other members of the Latvian Arajs Commando under his command assisted the Germans in killing more than 2,000 Jews in the Slutzk ghetto. Mr Faris and the SIU were not concerned about issues of identification which were so important in other cases that have been considered around the world, including the very famous issue of Mr Ivan Demjanjuk  and his identity. First of all, 
 Mr Faris established that there were overseas witnesses and then he established that there were local witnesses, some of whom I have spoken to personally. Some of them were about 12 or 13 and had known Mr Ozols all of their lives.
Thirdly, was a killing order from SS Obersturmfuhrer Strauch in which Hilfsbeamten or supernumerary Ozols name was specifically included as a person responsible for various killings. Finally, in the state court of Hamburg in 1979, the German government requested an interview and extradition of Mr Ozols to participate in various other trials that were taking place against members of the Arajs Commando. The German court established all of the details of Mr Ozols' presence at all of the three incidents that Mr Faris QC recommended, via the DPP, to the Attorney-General as the reason for a prima facie case being necessary.
In North Queensland recently, a person who some would describe as an elderly pensioner has been charged as the alleged perpetrator of the murder of two children that took place more than 20 years ago. No-one in this parliament would suggest that because this gentleman is an age pensioner no charges should be pursued against him. The statute of limitations does not apply, according to any of us, to the charge of murder, and I think it is simply being consistent that we ought to apply it in these cases ourselves. The member for Kooyong spoke of the moral imperative that drives a democratic society like Australia in these kinds of issues, in remembering why we participated in that great struggle for democracy during the Second World War. I believe that this moral imperative should have been behind all of our actions in dealing with all of these issues, including the government's welcome amendment to repeal section 22 of the War Crimes Act 1945.
If people feel that perhaps these issues do not apply to Australia, I remind them of events that took place immediately after the dropping of the Special Investigations Unit and the policy fatigue that took place at that time. I go first to what happened in Bosnia. The war crimes that took place there led to the United Nations setting up special war crimes investigators. Ironically, the person who is now most prominent in seeking prosecutions against war criminals in Bosnia and Serbia is our own Graham Blewitt, who was the last head of the Special Investigations Unit that was too early sent into legal oblivion by a previous government and whose work should have been taken up by the current government.
If we look at the disgraceful situation perpetrated by Indonesian military authorities in East Timor after the 30 August referendum, the widespread international community view and the view of the UN Human Rights Commissioner is that war crimes and crimes against humanity may have been perpetrated in East Timor by the then military authorities of Indonesia. If people feel that in dropping our interest in war crimes we have in any way contributed to this expectation in some areas of the international community that war crimes and crimes against humanity such as those perpetrated in Bosnia and East Timor have in any way been lessened, we stand partially to blame for that development.
I conclude by indicating my support for these amendments to the War Crimes Act 1945. I hope that the now democratic countries of the Baltic take the opportunity to use Australia's new ability to assist them in extraditing the two or three people who have been talked about internationally as people who may be in Australia and who, according to the democratic and historical experience of those Baltic countries, it is seen as essential to bring to those countries for trials and examination of their activities during World War II against citizens of those countries. I commend this amendment to the War Crimes Act 1945.

name: Thompson, Cameron, MP
text:
—I think we all agree that we do not want to see Australia a haven for war criminals. The War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999  that we are debating here today will lead to the repeal of section 22 of the War Crimes Act. That will mean there will no longer be any need to establish a prima facie case prior to the extradition of people overseas for trial on issues in relation to alleged war crimes.
One of the important principles involved is that international boundaries should not allow a person to evade criminal justice. One of the things that is referred to again and again in the literature surrounding this legislation is the fact that over the years we have seen, across the world, closed borders. Those closed borders, and the lack of ability to view proceedings behind those borders, have resulted in and facilitated fairly lurid media headlines from time to time when it has not been possible for a trial to proceed because of allegations occurring on one side of the boundary and people existing on the other side of the boundary.
For example, I refer to some of the headlines that have gone before in the Australian Jewish News such as that on August 27 this year. It said, `Nazis in Australia: too late, says expert', and the article refers to media revelations that Australia secretly recruited known SS members, former Nazi storm-troopers and Nazi party members to work here as scientists and technicians after World War II. The same article states:
Not every German was a Nazi and not every Nazi was a war criminal.
But there is in that kind of a lurid presentation of the details a clear imputation that some of those people may have been involved in war crimes.
What is a war crime? I will not go into all the details here. A war crime is defined in sections 6, 7 and 8 of the War Crimes Act. I am quoting here from an article by Gillian Triggs:
A serious crime is a war crime if it was:
(a) committed:
	 (i)  in the course of political, racist or religious persecution; or
	 (ii)	 with the intent to destroy in whole or in part a national, ethnic, racial or religious group, as such, and
(b)	 committed in the territory of a country when the country was involved in a war or when the territory of the country was subject to an occupation.
War is defined by section 5 to mean war `in so far as it occurred in Europe in the period beginning on 1 September 1939 and ending on 8 May 1945'.
That basically sets out what the War Crimes Act is dealing with, but I can go on into the article by Gillian Triggs and look at the consideration of people where, as I stated earlier, the allegations involved activities that were alleged to have occurred on the other side of borders that were for some time closed. I want to refer now to a case involving Mr Polyukhovich and the article by Gillian Triggs. She says:
Mr Polyukhovich was seventy-two when, on 26 January, 1990, he was charged with nine offences (later amended to eighteen) alleging the murder of twenty-four men, women and children and of having been knowingly involved in the murder of 850 Jews in the Ukraine between 1941 and 1943. The day before he was to appear in the Adelaide Magistrates Court committal proceedings, Polyukhovich was shot in the chest and wounded. This delayed proceedings but did not cause them to be terminated.
A litte further on in the article she says:
Polyukhovich was committed to stand trial in the Supreme Court of South Australia on two charges relating to the killings of six people. 

In other words, prima facie evidence was found to exist in that case—that is, prima facie evidence as established within the Australian judicial system.
The subsequent trial of Polyukhovich in the Supreme Court of South Australia came to an abrupt end when the indictments were quashed for lack of evidence. Apparently the court was not satisfied as to the credibility of the witnesses and was not prepared to allow such evidence as there was to go to the jury.
That case indicates an example in which prima facie evidence was found to exist. What we are dealing with here is the idea that it is not necessary to find prima facie evidence, and that is certainly the case in all other matters apart from allegations of war crimes. In all other matters, dealings between international authorities occur because of extradition treaties on which there is no necessary evidence at all. All that is needed to be established is that there is a domestic law in Australia—in other words, an extradition agreement with that other country—and that there is an allegation and a request from that country for that to proceed.
When we consider the needs for extradition, under the Extradition Act 1988, which will become the relevant act once section 22 of the War Crimes Act is repealed, there are protections in place. I want to refer in particular to the protections given to the Attorney-General. Before someone can be extradited, the Attorney-General has to be satisfied that there is no extradition objection in relation to the offence; that on surrender to the extradition country the person will not be subjected to torture; and that, where the offence is punishable by a penalty of death, special circumstances apply.
The Attorney-General must consider one of the following alternatives: one, the person will not be tried for the offence; two, if the person is tried for the offence, the death penalty will not be imposed on the person; three, if the death penalty is imposed on the person, it will not be carried out. Further, the Attorney-General can satisfy himself or herself that a special assurance has been given in relation to the person. I am not covering all the specific details, but the Attorney-General also has discretion to consider that the person should be surrendered in relation to the particular offence.
The international principle is that extradition proceedings have no function in determining whether someone is guilty or innocent. They are simply an administrative matter. Is the person concerned liable under our law to be surrendered up to another country to face trial? In other words, do we recognise their law and do they recognise ours? That is the basis on which an extradition agreement exists or does not exist.
In the past there have been questions about whether people extradited to Warsaw Pact countries, under the former Warsaw Pact, would be provided with a fair trial. We have all heard allegations—it is probably a clear fact—that under those regimes there were political juntas and military juntas conducting show trials. There would be real concern in the mind of the average Australian that those things would have been occurring. However, since the collapse of the Soviet empire and the break-up of Yugoslavia, many ex-Warsaw Pact nations are now moving towards the mainstream in terms of their governance and in terms of their legal system.
I think we would all have seen the notes that have been issued illustrating this bill which list a number of countries from that area. Is there any reason why we should not develop extradition agreements under our law with those particular countries? Can we establish those agreements? I would submit that we should be setting up those agreements. As I said, those borders have been an impediment for years to the proper review of people's behaviour or 
 crimes alleged against them. Now is the opportunity to clear the air on those issues. Therefore, obviously I commend this bill.
We would have to establish an extradition treaty with those nations before we would be obliged under our law to give up someone. I had a particular look at some of those ex-Warsaw Pact nations. I asked myself, `What other ones are there, apart from the ones listed as moving down this path? Are there some recalcitrant ones?' Obviously there are. For example, what is the position with Serbia? Would Australians in general like to see someone extradited to Serbia? I think many people would be concerned about that. Clearly that is not going to happen because we do not have any extradition agreement with them. We have nothing within our domestic law that would require an Attorney-General to give up someone for trial in Serbia.
As these nations move towards the mainstream in terms of their governance, then we can make these agreements and we can then see justice done. Where there is an allegation made, it can be followed down the burrow. People can then determine whether there is a case to answer under the appropriate regime, and the decision can be made.
There have been some examples. In 1997, Latvia sought documents regarding alleged genocide and war crimes by Mr Kalejs during the Second World War. It is possible that Latvia may seek to extradite Mr Kalejs when it has completed its examination of all this material, and an extradition treaty would facilitate that. By removing this requirement for an examination of prima facie evidence in such a case, Australia is clearing the way for such a thing to occur.
Another example occurred when Lithuania sought information from Australia on alleged war crimes by Antanas Gudelis of Adelaide. A report in the Australian Jewish News of 30 July 1999 says:
Mr Gudelis, 87, immigrated from Germany with his wife 50 years ago and became an Australian citizen. He is suspected of the mass murder of civilians in the Lithuania town of Kupiskis during World War II.
The article goes on to say:
Mr Gudelis was previously investigated by Australia's Special Investigations Unit (SIU), but prosecution did not proceed. The SIU was set up in 1987 following allegations of alleged war criminals . . . It investigated a number of cases of alleged war criminals under the War Crimes Act 1945.
Four cases were referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions, but none was successfully prosecuted before the SIU was closed down by the Federal Government in 1992. The government has been criticised since then for lack of political will on the issue of alleged war criminals living in Australia.
I think this legislation puts an end to that kind of criticism.
—Why?
—Because it provides the opportunity for these people to be tried in areas where these things are alleged to have occurred. It is reasonable for people to continue to actively question the government on this issue because it is a very emotional one, but I do think that by opening the door for scrutiny overseas by the very people who are making the allegations, and by not keeping this impediment of prima facie evidence, Australia is coming to a position that is workable. I would be interested to hear what the member opposite has to say about that.
It is a situation that is difficult. It has raised tremendous expectations in the past, only to have them dashed. I do not anticipate that that sort of thing is going to stop in future just because we do this, particularly so many years after the fact, but the point is, steps are being taken.
I would like to reiterate that the end of the communist era means that these issues can be opened up to scrutiny. They can be tried in an environment which Australians would have trust in and would believe to be accurate. It means that the system in those countries is increasingly transparent. We in Australia need to facilitate the flow of justice in relation to these very emotional issues.
As I said, this bill opens the way for that to occur. I welcome the support that has been forthcoming from members opposite in relation to it. It is important that such an emotional issue does not degenerate into a point scoring exercise. On the whole, that kind of temptation has been avoided in the past, and I hope that will continue to be the case in the future. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

name: Theophanous, Andrew, MP
text:
—It is my pleasure to speak on the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 , and I support the legislation. However, I have to say this legislation is long overdue because it is at least seven years since most of the Iron Curtain countries gained their independence and yet we are only just acting on this matter now. It has been far too slow in coming.
Both sides of the House are, I think, open to criticism in relation to this matter. The Executive Council of Australian Jewry is correct in saying that the whole episode of war criminals from the Second World War in relation to Australia—and the approach of all governments—is a very sorry story. The fact is that, during that period after the war, a number of Nazis, fascists and people of very dubious background were allowed into Australia. When I consider the sorts of checks we make now on people who have legitimate reasons to come to Australia, as compared with what we did then with regard to some people whose background and motivation were amazing, I think this matter needed to be examined.
I have been around for a few years. In 1987, thinking that we would be doing something, I supported the bill which set up the commission. By 1992, when there was not a single successful prosecution, those of us who took an interest in the matter were appalled. Not only had it cost the nation several million dollars but, as the honourable member for Denison has now pointed out in relation to this bill, we were frustrated by certain other factors. One was that in every case, rather than dealing with this matter in cooperation with other countries, we thought we would simply deal with it by trying people, or thinking about trying people, under Australian law with Australian practice. They would then have to pass the stricter criteria that are at present in our system.
That would have been okay if our nation and certain sections of our bureaucracy had not covered up the fact that, when these characters came to Australia at that time, some of them knew of their background. Why has there not been an inquiry into this matter? We have all sorts of parliamentary and other inquiries but we have never had an inquiry into this very serious issue—the cover-up of war criminals who came to Australia after the Second World War. Yes, we had a War Crimes Tribunal established, but its business was to find individuals, not to look into the question of what actually happened in the Australian processes that allowed these people to come during that period. This is very serious: I am not sure that we have learnt from our history.
I take this opportunity to say that I hope the parliament at some stage looks into this matter, looking into the role of our intelligence agencies, our immigration department and other bureaucracies that were involved in covering up the fact that some of these people who came 
 out here had been directly responsible for the killing of a large number of innocent people, including Jewish people.
I now turn to the question of what happened when we did form the War Crimes Tribunal and the sorry tale from 1987 to 1992—we never got a single conviction. We have been criticised in international circles about this. I remember that, at the time they wound it up, we were told that we had done our best and we had gone around trying to find information. In the case of the one person they managed to actually get before a court, it did not proceed in the end because they claimed that the information was not sufficiently powerful in relation to our judicial system.
One wonders whether it would not have been better to start up an investigation into what actually happened in terms of the total process rather than set up a narrow tribunal that looked into the prosecution of individuals. Why were all those people who came here—they may since have died or there may not be sufficient evidence of all their misbehaviour—allowed into this country? Why were they not checked? Who covered up for them? We never investigated that.
We are now being told by the minister in her second reading speech that the reason for this amendment is that things have changed in Europe, and that some of the countries that were behind the Iron Curtain are now part of the European family and we therefore needed to make some extradition treaties with them. But there is a problem: we have suddenly discovered that the criterion called the prima facie case that we have in the legislation under section 22 does not apply to all countries. Not all countries have a similar criterion. Why we suddenly discovered this after all these years is an interesting question.
As the honourable member for Blair said earlier, even if we formed these extradition agreements with Latvia, Estonia, Lithuania and several other countries in the former Soviet Union and perhaps even countries in the former Yugoslavia, because they have a different system of dealing with this—that is, a civil code system instead of the same criminal code system of the kind that we have—we still would not be able to get the extraditions going. That is why we want to get rid of section 22. I agree with that; the only thing is that we should have done it years ago. Many of the people who have been guilty of these crimes have now passed away or they are very old, and the possibility of putting together evidence, even under the civil code system, becomes much more difficult.
Having said all that, I think we should now actively take advantage of the passing of this legislation and say that Australia is ready to cooperate with these countries in cases like this. We should, firstly, speedily ensure that we have extradition agreements and, secondly, where there are requests from these countries, deal with them under the civil code system of that particular country so that people can be extradited and dealt with for the things that they have done.
I said earlier that maybe we have not completely learned the lesson of that previous experience. I would be interested to know whether the War Crimes Amendment Bill or the War Crimes Act as it stands will actually be applicable to the crimes against humanity issues that have arisen in relation to a number of places. I am referring particularly to former Yugoslavia. Will this legislation allow us to carry out extraditions against people who may have been involved in crimes against humanity in the former Yugoslavia? Will this legislation ensure that people who may have come from the former Yugoslavia who may be guilty of crimes against humanity are covered by the amended War Crimes Act? I would be interested in the minister's response to this issue.
The terminology has changed in international forums from `war crimes' to `crimes against humanity'. This is important because of what happens in internal civil war type situations. In situations where there are ethnic conflicts within a particular country, there is no formal declaration of war but there are crimes against humanity. Will this amended legislation be able to deal with that sort of issue? If not, I would suggest that we have missed an opportunity to actually get Australia involved in an international effort in relation to these matters.
We have had a number of sensational incidents in relation to this term `crimes against humanity', the most famous being the Pinochet case in Britain, where Spain requested the extradition of the former president and dictator Mr Pinochet for crimes against humanity committed while he was president of his country.
Let us assume that we had a Pinochet type personality here in Australia and a country requested the extradition of that person. Would this legislation, as amended, cover that sort of incident? Would it cover that type of case? If not, why not? If we have amended legislation, why haven't we taken account of this matter in order to deal with that sort of contingency? And you do not have to be a president. You can be a significant player who has been responsible for crimes against humanity in one of these situations—in a civil war, in an ethnic conflict or, as in the Pinochet case, where the crime is against one's own people.
I would be interested to find out whether the amended legislation is going to cover these situations. If not, I would like to say that I am pretty disappointed that it does not and that there ought to have been further amendments to this legislation to deal with that sort of issue. If the intention of this legislation is to overcome bottlenecks in relation to the past, in relation to 30 or 40 years ago, we should also have learnt from the hard lessons of that time and be ready to deal with more contemporary cases.
We are talking now about dealing with crimes against humanity in relation to East Timor. We have made quite a bit of fuss about that, and of course I agree that we ought to be pursuing it. But what about our own legislation? For example, what if somebody from Indonesia manages to become a permanent Australian resident or citizen and it is discovered that that person was involved in East Timor human rights abuses? Would that be covered under this legislation?
I think it is very important that we confront these issues. We do not want to be left with the following comment made by the Vice-President of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry at the end of the Australian process when he said:
Now we have the benefit of 10 years to look at the legislation that was adopted—
that was the 1989 amendments to the War Crimes Act—
we can see that it failed. It not only failed to deal with that one situation, it failed to deal with the other cases.
What is left is a situation where the information, the allegations, the research is all out there and there's still more that can be conceivably done if the government was willing to devote the resources.
Perhaps that point ought to be taken on board as well. Perhaps we have not devoted sufficient resources in the right way when dealing with this issue.
As we move towards the new millennium and we look at casting off some of the worst aspects of our history, one of the worst things in our history has been the fact that war criminals were able to come to Australia and survive here when they had done awful things and that, by the time we got around to doing something about it, many of them had either 
 passed away or the evidence had disappeared. We have not even seriously investigated why all of that happened.
When we are facing up to the future, when we have seen the situations that have occurred in various places around the world, especially in the former Yugoslavia, and we know that there may be people here who have been involved in some of these crimes, let us make sure that we have the weapons, that we have the legislation and that we have the political will to pursue any such people so that we do not repeat the episode which occurred after the Second World War in relation to the Nazis. I support the legislation.

name: Stone, Sharman, MP
text:
—in reply—I thank all members who have contributed to this debate. It was pleasing to hear that members of the opposition support the very important amendments contained in the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 . In particular, I was pleased to see the support from the opposition shadow minister for justice and customs, the member for Denison.
The member for Calwell, Dr Theophanous, raised a number of important issues. For example, he talked long and hard about the amendments contained in the bill being about 10 years overdue. It is indeed a shame that the previous government did not listen to the member for Calwell, who was part of that government. No doubt he called for those sorts of amendments in his time but the then government did not listen or respond. The good news is that this government has acted very promptly indeed, so we have before us today this bill which repeals section 22. This bill was introduced in 1998 but it lapsed when parliament was prorogued and it has been reintroduced very promptly following the re-election of the government. On that front, I should think that the member for Calwell is somewhat better pleased with the performance of this government in relation to the matter.
The member for Calwell was also very concerned in that he felt there had never been in this country any investigation of potential bureaucratic cover-up in relation to alleged war criminals slipping through the net immediately after the Second World War, and since, coming into this country. He alleged that perhaps there was some bureaucratic cover-up at that time and there had never been any concern from any government of the day to check allegations which I presume have been made over a number of years.
Under Prime Minister Robert Menzies there was an independent inquiry which looked at whether or not there was any incompetence or deliberate cover-up in terms of people coming to this country who were potential or alleged war criminals. I refer the member to Parliamentary Paper No. 90/1987, which will give him access to the findings of that inquiry. I will read briefly from paragraph (3) of the section headed `Findings':
While Australian officers in Europe endeavoured to prevent the acceptance for migration to Australia of persons responsible for war crimes, and these endeavours must have prevented many war criminals from entering Australia, there were serious limitations, particularly in early years, in numbers and geographical spread of staff available to do the necessary checking and equally serious gaps in the data against which Australian security officers would have made their checks, particularly in relation to non-Germans. These limitations and gaps would have made possible the entry of persons responsible for war crimes although the number of persons so admitted would have been a minute proportion of the enormous number of persons who migrated to Australia in the post-war years.
Paragraph (4) refers to chapter 7 of the report in the following terms:
. . . no person admitted into Australia under arrangements with U.K. or U.S. intelligence agencies, to the knowledge of Australian authorities, appears to have been the object of charges or allegations as to 
 commission of war crimes although there is a possibility that, particularly before 1956, former employees of such agencies may have entered Australia without the knowledge of Australian authorities.
Certainly, the Liberal government of the day tried very hard to sort out if there were problems deliberately perpetrated when it came to letting people into this country who should not be here.
The member for Melbourne Ports was most concerned about the US current affairs program 20/20, which screened last week. It suggested that it is quite an easy thing to live in Australia as a war criminal. The member for Melbourne Ports was quite rightly concerned about Australia's reputation if that sort of thing were true, and he seemed to think that that in fact was the case. That television program was followed up last week by the 7.30 Report.
Of course, the member for Melbourne Ports, like the US 20/20 producers and Australia's own 7.30 Report producers, failed to stress the fact that we have very different systems in place when it comes to how we go about prosecuting alleged war criminals. For example, the US uses the Immigration Nationality Act 1952, which allows for the deportation of any alien who was simply associated with the Nazi government or any area occupied by the forces of that government with any established Nazi assistance. There is no need to prove a suspect has any personal involvement in any war crime. The proceedings are civil. So the association has to be proved only on the balance of probabilities. As well, if the suspect concealed wartime activities when applying for a US visa and that concealment was found to be a wilful and material misrepresentation, then that is also additional grounds for deportation.
On the other hand, Australia must, under the War Crimes Act 1945, prove the actual commission of a war crime within the meaning of the act or an ancillary offence such as aiding and abetting beyond a reasonable doubt, and it is subject to rigorous criminal, evidentiary and procedural requirements. The suspects have the same rights in Australia under the law as any other Australian suspected of committing a serious crime. So the Australia government of the day—and I think most of us would agree it would continue—was concerned that the fairness of the Australian criminal justice system should not be perverted for the sake of easy popular convictions based on inadequate evidence.
Deportation was not an easy option under Australian law. Until 1998, there was a limit of 10 years before the commission of an offence of giving false information in applying for Australian citizenship after which a person would no longer be liable for deportation for that offence. In 1998, our government removed that time limit, but the effect of the amendment was prospective only. Therefore, people who have already received the benefit of the time limit cannot be deported now under the amended provision. I hope that the member for Melbourne Ports understands that we have different systems. It is easy to say that the US has many points and Australia zero, but that is comparing apples and pears. Let me reiterate that the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999  deals with very serious issues of a long time ago, but time has not indeed dimmed any Australian's sense of justice when it comes to prosecuting and assisting with prosecutions of those alleged of war crimes.
Section 22 imposes a specific requirement for the content of extradition requests to Australia with respect to conduct which would be covered by the act—in other words, certain crimes committed in Europe during World War II. Currently such requests must be accompanied by the presentation of evidence which establishes a prima facie case that the person has committed the alleged war crime. The main justification for the repeal of section 22 is that it is no longer 
 appropriate to include this onerous requirement for war crime extraditions, particularly following the emergence of newly independent states in Europe from behind the Iron Curtain.
In principle, Australia is interested in establishing modern extradition arrangements with these countries which have now been accepted as members of the Council of Europe. So the enactment of this bill, together with the completion of these new modern extradition arrangements, will increase significantly our ability to cooperate with other countries which seek our assistance in bringing alleged World War II criminals to trial. I think all Australians would be with us today in agreeing that this is a very important amendment. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
—If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Swan, Wayne, MP
text:
—Today I would like to pay tribute to all the members of the Lilley Pricewatch team. They do important work detecting price rises in supermarkets. They act as a thermometer detecting heat seeking price rises.
The Pricewatch surveys were commenced by my predecessor, Mrs Elaine Darling, and they have been carried on by me since 1993. From relatively humble beginnings, the survey has expanded to a total of 27 supermarkets located within and adjacent to the electorate of Lilley, which is situated in the northern suburbs of Brisbane. A fixed basket of 38 grocery items is surveyed at irregular periods by a group of volunteers. Naturally, we have no prior knowledge of any promotions or specials involving items included in our basket and we record both the everyday shelf price and a special price, if applicable.
We take extreme care to ensure the accuracy of our surveys. On receipt, they are scanned to establish whether any apparent errors are recorded. If uncertainty exists, a second check of the store is carried out. The results are maintained on spreadsheets which provide the data to enable an analysis to be carried out. For much of this year, we have been reporting price increases at a rate three times the increase in the CPI and that is a matter of extreme concern.
In particular, I would like to pay tribute to a number of people from the Pricewatch team: Mavis Sinclair, Gaye Tatasciore, Edwina Anderson, Valmai Fisher, Carol Langfield, Brigit Langer, Eunice Jenkin, Bernie Kingston, Louin Wright, Noeline Coran, Sylvia Davey, Gregory Hughes, Christine Gordan, Ben Thompson, Gwen Thomas, Janette Ryan, Bobby Flanagan and Jules Shegog, Joan Ross, Claire Don, Rona Belton, Lola Palmsellers, Karina King, Ailsa Tryst, Gwenneth Smith, Maisie Llwellyen, Donna Smart, Louise Koster and Janette Bohan.
The other thing that there is a lot of community concern about is increases in the price of milk. This year, in Brisbane, the price of milk has risen something like 12 per cent, and that is when there has been an official inflation rate of 1.1 per cent. The price of a litre of milk 
 was $1.17 at the beginning of this year and it is now $1.32. Many people living in the northern suburbs of Brisbane are extremely concerned and have written to me about this matter. For example, a letter from Taigum said:
I am thoroughly disgusted at the increases in milk prices. We have two children to encourage to drink plenty of milk so they grow up healthy and have strong bones and teeth, but the more it costs to buy each week, the less I encourage them to drink.
From Boondall:
My husband and I receive a Carer's Pension and are caring for three intellectually disabled people (also on Pensions) in our own home. We have no other source of revenue—savings or super. If these types of price rises continue and are not off-set by pension rises, we will soon find it impossible to care for our charges.
From Deagon:
With the rise in the price of milk, we are now in a situation where it is cheaper to give our children Cocoa-Cola than to provide them with this necessary nutrition of milk, and have no doubt this will happen with the poorer people of our country.
People are being savaged by price rises. I am extremely concerned that this is yet another example of price increases being introduced ahead of the GST. If price increases on milk are already outstripping inflation 10 times over, what will happen to the price of milk when the rate of inflation is five per cent, as has been predicted by analysts like the Commonwealth Bank and now the Reserve Bank? KPMG, in a government sponsored study, have already predicted a GST from 1 July will add at least 7.5 per cent to food prices and this will be on top of the pre-GST price rises currently hitting consumers.
If the Howard government and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission cannot protect families from price hikes on basic dietary necessities like milk and bread before the GST is introduced, I am extremely concerned at what actions we can expect in a post-GST environment.
Following the increase in the price of milk, I decided to look at the legislation to see whether the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission would do anything about it. I was surprised to find that they could do nothing about it unless there was a special reference from the Treasurer to the ACCC about milk in Brisbane. Accordingly, I have written to the Treasurer, Mr Costello, saying:
. . . I earnestly request that you exercise your powers under s.18(1) of the Prices Surveillance Act 1983 and require the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission to hold an enquiry into the two price rises by Pauls Limited and the two rises announced by Dairy Farmers which have occurred since deregulation. Although the rises did not coincide exactly, they became effective within one week of each other.
The terms of reference should include an investigation into the possibility of collusion in setting prices and also whether Pauls Limited is using its pre-eminent market strength to manipulate the Brisbane market.
(Time expired)
